content:
ry 1, 2016
												Pinning down precisely what makes the world of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings so enthralling took me some time. It's not that the fiction is particularly "mature," though that's undoubtedly a term that will be tossed around until the next hyper-gritty fantasy game pops up. Think about it for a second: The Witcher, Geralt of Rivia, is a crag-faced, cat-eyed, gravelly-voiced mutant hardass who only stops screwing and fighting when occasion calls for a philosopher, at which point he dutifully duels scholars and monarchs with a tongue as sharp as either of his two swords. He is a character straight out of a 15-year-old boy's misused English notebook; the wounded warrior poet who, by the way, gets all the consequence-free sex he can handle, since he's totally shooting blanks, bro. And sure, he's stoic -- but he's also got a sensitive soul somewhere beneath that scar-laden chest of his, damn it.No, what makes the Witcher's world so absorbing is an amazingly cohesive and consistent visual vocabulary that is -- and I know this is going to sound ridiculous -- far more logical than is typical for fantasy games. The impoverished fishermen of the riverside village of Flotsam shuffle around in nothing but ruddy underwear. Dumpy town guards patrol in filthy rags that still bear their national colors. Ornate attire is (for once) consigned solely to the upper class. Buildings look planted and properly dilapidated. This may seem a small thing, but from the first minutes of the game, it's clear how much effort has gone into researching how a society like the one portrayed would look; this medieval civilization, infused with -- but not dominated by -- magic and mystery (props to developer CD Projekt), is just awesome.Similarly impressive: the degree to which the story changes based on your actions. Game makers (and publishers, and shareholders, and preview writers) love to crow on about choices and consequences. Hell, if you buy the PR spin, every single BioWare game in the past decade has been a watershed moment for cause and effect in video game storytelling. But frankly, the lofty language usually leads to a letdown -- the best we usually get are mundane tics on a morality slider that may or may not unlock a new dialogue tree, or perhaps a new companion somewhere down the road. I'd go so far as to argue that the only stable of games that's been quietly, consistently offering a serious set of genuinely game-altering forks-in-the-road for nearly a decade now is Acquire's Way of the Samurai series.Not anymore.While we have the underlying storyline of murder, intrigue, and (more stupidly) amnesia to which The Witcher 2 continually returns, the minutiae is wholly malleable. The allies Geralt makes on his journey and the enemies he combats shift with your mood swings; larger decision points alter the landscape of the world dramatically, but even minor events can cause repercussions much later in the game -- and how the whole thing ends is entirely your choice. Reading after-action reports from fellow players is like a game unto itself. Nobody seems to experience quite the same scenarios.Not all is well in the Pontar Valley, however. Combat, for instance, is a serious problem made even worse by a poorly implemented, obscenely difficult and unhelpful opening segment. Plow into battle unprepared, and you might as well expect the worst: Even on moderate difficulty levels, this is not a game in which potential sources of aid can be ignored. Traps, bombs, magic, daggers, pre-battle potions... every tool in Geralt's arsenal is an absolute necessity.Once I got the basics down, the extremely acrobatic, constantly active feint-and-parry style of Witcher warfare became seriously enjoyable -- just don't expect the prologue section to teach you much of anything valuable. And even when I finally felt like a proper monster-hunting mutant badass, I occasionally came across the rare room or fight so absurd that I had to wonder if CD Projekt understood the limitations of its own combat system. Geralt in a room too cramped to allow for falling back and trap placement? Battles before which you have no time to meditate and drink potions? No thanks.Worse still, the user interface only exacerbates the combat system's flaws by forcing the player to keep an eye on everything but the melee itself. Geralt's vigor (read: mana) meter, health meter, buff/debuff indicators, and equipped spells/items are all scattered across the screen, which is a serious drawback when you're surrounded by screeching harpies.But not even a terrible introductory sequence can take away from what is otherwise a fantastic game. Sure, the story is goofy, and at times the fighting is offensively clunky. The world isn't as colossal as the first Witcher's, and the ending is a bit of a tease. But in a time when I rarely bother to finish single-player games, I'm happy (and slightly embarrassed) to say that I'm already several hours into a second playthrough of Assassins of Kings. And I can't think of a better compliment than that.Pros:Engrossing worldstory has more branches than a sycamoretechnically astonishinggreat voice acting.Cons:Combat takes getting used to and never becomes fantasticpacing problemstoo many quick-time events.My Rating: 9.2/10

content:
, 2014
												I highly recommend this game and this is why:Storyline:The storyline is packed with distrust, politics and personal agendas which I found very interesting. Every character had their own ambitions, attitudes and reason for their actions. I found that I either liked or was undecided about a character, with a few characters that I hated. The storyline flowed well and almost every side quest made sense given the situation that the character was in. You even had some sidequests were you had to track creatures nest and blow them up which was fun and a different version to the usual kill x collect x formula . You were able to make multiple choses in the game and almost every chose matter towards either the main storyline or a sidequest and possibly both. Many of the choses that you choose from had its positive and negatives. You rarely got an option that seemed like the best option but more like 3 or 4 options that could be good but also could be bad. I like this and made me think of what option I should choose. Some warning there is a lot of dialogue about the political issues of Geralt's world and they do shoot out a lot of names which may push some people away. But if your intrigued about  political struggles, regicide, betrayal, mystery and even some romance then you will love this storyline. Gameplay:Utterly love the gameplay. It is an action rpg with a skill tree, some what, similar to diablo or other action rpgs. But the overall gameplay is different then your typical action rpg where you kill a huge mobs of monster one right after the other. In this game you do more exploring around and talking to people than killing creatures. But when you do kill creatures they are incredibly dynamic battles were you have options on how you want to kill your foe. Do you want to ensare the creature in a trap and stab it with you sword or do you want to shock it with a bomb and run in for the fatal blow. Also you do not stand their and fight the monster exchanging blows, no you try to dodge or parry the blows so you don't get killed because you can be overwhelmed in the game pretty easily if your not careful. Oh but dont forget your potions. There is an alchemy system where you can make potions using herbs that you find in abundance in the wild as well as oils and poisons that can be added to your weapon for a short period of time. These potions will increase your stats, or allow you to see in the dark, some even give you advantages at a cost of another stat being reduced. These potions are extremely helpful and usually only last around 5 to 10 minutes unless you have some points in the alchemy skill tree. Potions can only be used before a battle starts and you have a limit on how many potions you can drink. So I enjoyed thinking about what potions I should use and when I should use them. You are also capable of creating bombs, traps, armor and weapons which I have seen before, but still adds something to the game, especially the bombs and traps. Graphics:The graphics is just amazing for its time and I was suprised at the differences between the looks of some characters that were from the first Witcher game. I also liked how original the creatures looked  in comparison to many other games I have played. This difference added to the dark tone of the game quite well. The graphics made exploring around a lot more enjoyable overall. Replayability:There is some good replay value to this game. There are several different difficulty levels that you can play on, and the storyline branches out in two different ways. Therefore, you will have to play the game again to see the other part of the storyline that you missed the first time. There are also differences in sidequests depending on which storyline branch you choose as well as different results to the side quests depending on your choices.Cons:Yes, like all games there are some cons to this game. The big one is... the map. It might just be me but I found the map to be utterly confusing to understand.  Some things on the map that looked like walls ended up not being walls and other parts of the map that didn't look like walls ended up being walls. I was playing on the controller and there seemed to be no shortcut button to see the bigger version of the map, you had to open up the selection menu and press map every single time which got on my nerves a bit. Another con to this game is the game's inability to work properly. Sometimes the game would either slow down making gameplay difficult or just crash. Also this issue could very much be an issue with my computer and not the game. Another issue I had with the game was although the towns were well thought out and dynamic the same people walking around kept saying the exact same two or three lines every single time you would pass by them, unless you were having a conversation with them. Next time I hope that the people have atleast a few more lines that they could say.  So overall, this is a great game that you should play to get prepared for Witcher 3, which looks amazing.

Обязательно куплю =)

content:
y 2, 2014
												Let me begin by first congratulating you on clicking this wonderful game. Kudos to you. Let me next congratulate you for looking at the reviews of this game, as rightly you should. Now let me slap you in the f*cking jaw for clicking on "Negative Reviews". Entrance a little too strong? Well consider it a wake up call.If you have played many an RPG and completed it with a lingering craving for depth and lore, then this game is your healing salve. This game has some of the richest storytelling I have ever had the pleasure of being part of, paired with it's sheer beauty and somewhat impressive mod support, you can not go wrong with this purchase. The voice acting is on point, similar to that of Fable, with its regional 'Typically British' dialect which is laced with humour and one-liners. The gameplay, whilst some suggest is 'clunky', works well considering the type of game this is. The graphics are demanding, but if you have the power to run this at high settings, they will leave you awestruck. The storyline is fresh and cleverly written (with enough room for plenty of side quests), and although it seems typically linear, the areas you visit are open enough to allow you to breath. The game is without a doubt targetted at a more mature audience, with an abundance of nakedness particularly from the female cast (which is brilliant for us single men - am I right?!) as well as a great deal of 'curse' words throughout. I can not say exactly how to play this game, nor can I elaborate on how much you will enjoy it - you quite literally just have to sit down and indulge its richness and take your time, let yourself break away from the quest grinding, go explore, talk to NPC's, loot houses, do some crafting... whatever it is you take delight in, just... do it. Its simple, and your decision to purchase this game should be too. The negative reviews that flood this page genuinely are talking out of their ars*s, their play time alone is enough to suggest they havent actually PLAYED the game. They have obviously gotten past the tutorial and cried because everything wasn't handed to them on a silver plate. For roughly the 6th time now I've seen this game go on sale for less than £5... If you are worrying about "wasting" £5 then you have issues. Seriously, you could find that on the street. Or you could go busking for an hour, whatever. Buy it.

content:
ry 26, 2015
												When I played the Witcher 1, I enjoyed it, but felt it had some annoying bits which unfortunately lessened the overall experience.In The Witcher 2, almost anything I was bothered with before is fixed. The combat is much improved. It's not perfect, but it's an solid improvement. There's also a mod out there that changes the combat fairly significant, for better or for worse.The story is awesome, although I feel the first one had more of an impact. It starts right after the first one but it gives enough info to still get the general gist of the story. I still highly recommend you play the first game since it's still a good game and you won't get lost here.The graphics are amazing. It's really jaw-dropping, especially once when you realize that it came out in the same year as Skyrim. It's simply stunning. Ubersampling is nice as it makes the obvious aliasing disappear, but it taxes even my GTX 970. You may prefer turning it off completely and dealing with the aliasing or using SweetFX.The music was less memorable to me than the first one. There wasn't anything I really particularly liked, but in general it's acceptable. The music might be the weakest part of the game for me, it just wasn't really noteworthy. It's not bad, but compared to the Witcher 1 it's meh.The content in this game is huge. I've played it twice as much as I have the first game. Without spoiling anything, you have to make a significant choice at a certain point which changes the game so much it's as if it's completely new. While there's still no jumping, and some invisible walls, they never irritated me in my playthrough. The maps are so large and the motion of climbing and descending cliffs are fluid. Signs and potions were a much bigger deal in this game than the last. I played it on normal difficulty, and while not as hard as Dark Souls, without a proper strategy and using brewing potions you're going to die...very easily.One noteworthy con is that the skill tree alchemy is useless. There's a limit to the number of skill points you get, and you'd much rather spend them on tangible things that affect your overall combat skills, not potions. Similarly, I probably used only one mutagen in the whole game. There's a wide range of weapons and armor in the game, so you won't really need to buy from merchants. You'll likely want to craft them yourself, or find good ones through quests and loot. Also this is personal preference but I found a gamepad to be better than KB+M, ignoring the inventory which is good with a KB+M, but annoying with a controller. I'd constantly unequip my boots when using one and found it really hard to manage my stuff. I still enjoy using a KB+M, although I think I prefer a controller with this game.It's a really solid game that any RPG fan should at least try. The environment is vast so you won't feel restricted even if it's not open world. The combat is good, not Dark Souls level but not Skyrim level either. Story is excellent as expected, with minor hiccups here and there.Although I feel like it's a great game, it's not perfect. Replayability is low for those who don't like seeing the same story again and combat can be tedious and downright frustrating at times (Not to mention targeting sucks).You'll want to save often as dying can send you way far back but too many saves causes frequent crashing. There's no way to move quicker, no sprinting or mounts. There's rolling, but it can't be done in areas like towns where they don't want your sword out. I also think the general atmosphere in the Witcher 1 was better, it had a darker and more serious tone although quite bleak.And...let's not forget the existence of the Witcher 3. I'll say this, play this game before TW3. TW3 is more of an improvement from TW2 to there compared to TW1 to TW2, and that's saying something. TW3 is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masterpiece, better music, visuals, gameplay, story and pretty much everything. Playing this and TW1 will make your TW3 experience that much better.

content:
15, 2015
												Definitely one of my most favorite games of all time and the best RPG EVER. In The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings you play as Geralt of Rivia, a legendary Witcher, based on the novels of Andrzej Sapkowski. Witchers are monster slayers for hire, with their mutated bodies and skills they wipe out monsters for a pay. But in this saga Geralt tries to regain his memory which he lost when fighting the Wild Hunt. (Read novels or play TW1/2 to know more about the story) on his way he has to deal with choices that have influence on your progess in the game.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------PROS+ Beautiful breathtaking graphics+ Epic long and interesting story+ Non-linear gameplay+ EXTREMELY immersive atmosphere+ Choices are important, in the game you always have the possibility to make choices you like and they all have their different consequences.+ Awesome soundtrack+ Interesting sidequests, unlike other RPGs or games these sidequests will totally not get you bored.+ Great and original characters+ Possibility to lay traps and hunt+ Different Monsters are spread throughout every location+ You are able to explore caves, areas, forests, etc+ Dynamic combat, dodging and attacking on the right time is VERY important. + Alchemy, you can craft potions and enhance your weapons in order to prepare for a battle.+ Really nice boss battles+ Skill tree that has 4 different ways with useful abilities, Training, Swordmanship, Magic, Alchemy+ Huge arsenal of weapons, magic light armor to heavy, obtainable through sidequests, lootable chests, barrels, etc throughout the whole world, even forgeable with the right materials and diagrams!+ Steam trading cardsCONSThis game totally has NO cons at all. I will just state some stuff that might be a con to other people. But in my opinion this game is way too perfect to have cons.- It really seems complicated in the beginning but you'll get used to it, dont give up to fast. (You'll understand what I mean if you play the game for the first time)- The combat system is not like your average RPG game, it has special and dynamic mechanics. Every enemy has a different pattern and the way you approach it is very important. Dont start rushing to kill your enemy, block and dodge till you learn how he moves and attacks. And maybe which magic is fatal to him. Even when playing it at easy mode you will struggle at a certain moment. Even I, myself, had died a couple of times at a boss battle because of not being serious and not knowing his pattern and style.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I double-recommend you this game, you'll totally fall in love with it. TW2 is a huge improvement to TW1, you can start at TW2 since you get the storyline told of TW1. TW3 is coming in May so while you are reading this review dont hesitate to get TW2 and prepare yourself for the third saga of The Witcher after you finished this game. The atmosphere, characters, maturity, choices (Which are VERY important to a lot of people, no one likes scripted stories and wants it their own way while they progess through the game) and many other stuff makes this game so special. This game is totally a must have for RPG lovers, even if you never tried RPGs or dont like them then try this one. Its worth the money and wont disappoint you.

content:
ber 28, 2014
												This review will not be kind, and I will be covering nothing but its flaws. If you're looking for someone to sing The Witcher 2's praises, there is nothing for you here. Just downvote me and move on.After spending 31 hours playing this game, I am finding it extremely hard to understand why this game and the developers (CDPR) are seen as some sort of hallowed, sanctified version of perfection and PC development done right. CDPR (and this game specifically) are brought up as a shining beacon almost every time there is a discussion about other devs making stupid decisions (whether it's QTEs in Tomb Raider, or devs not optimizing for the PC platform, etc), and I honestly could not tell you why.I really tried to like this game. I REALLY did. I played the vanilla version, and when I found the combat to be impossibly clunky and frustrating, I downloaded the Full Combat Rebalance mod, which definitely fixed the combat but unfortunately didn't fix any of the rest of the clunky, frustrating base game.-The texture work is distractingly disjointed (with awesome high-res textures right next to disgustingly cheap ones). Overall the game looks good, but why put hours and hours into an awesomely-done texture, and then stick it next to an asset ripped from Mario Kart 64?-The dialog is well-acted but was recorded at seemingly random volumes. Two characters talking calmly when all of a sudden one of them is talking REALLY REALLY LOUDLY, BUT STILL IN A NORMAL VOICE. It is beyond weird, and ridiculously lazy/shoddy.-The story is political intrigue by everyone towards everyone, secretly involving everyone. It gets UNBELIEVABLY tiresome, and you stop being surprised by it halfway through. Twists stop being interesting when that's all there is.-Dialog-based intimidation and charm are always successful (at least for me) so there's really no reason for them to even be there.-EVERYTHING is pre-scripted. fist-fights are QTEs, story battles that are supposed to be time-based will continue until you kill X number of enemies, and even WALKING THROUGH A DOOR is a scripted event. No loading screen, just stand in front of door and press X, Geralt centers himself against the door, opens it and goes through, and closes it behind him. Repeat for EVERY character! If you have a group of 5 guys, each individual one centers themselves, opens, walks through, and closes. Unimportant, sure, but it is SO HIDEOUSLY STUPID, and would be SO easy to fix.-Story fights that need to be repeated over and over and overandoverandoverandover.-Speaking of fights: Combat ends up being a slash or two and a sign or two, followed by 27 rolls around the arena while your signs recharge and the enemies un-bunch. Repeat for 40 minutes.-You cannot walk freely. You can't jump, and can only climb in pre-ordained places. You can only jump down in pre-ordained places. The whole thing is SUPER stuffy, and this game does NOT deserve to be called "open-world" at all.Ugh, there are so many more things that I could not stand about this game, but I'm done spending time on this "review" so I'll stop.If you've made it this far, it's worth saying that the game is not TERRIBLE. If you can put up with its problems, you might enjoy it. I, however, had been lead to think that it was a fantastic world-changing game, and when it turned out to be merely a good game marred by frustratingly stupid design decisions, I was beyond annoyed. Combat was a let-down, the plot was a let-down, movement in the world was a let-down, etc.I have been a PC gamer all my life. My Dad bought me the full version of Doom when I was 8. I cracked Dark Forces to work without the CD when I was 10. I've played Strife, Ultima Underworld, Wing Commander, Earthsiege & Mechwarrior, Jedi Knight, all the Descents (including both Freespaces), etc.I have ALWAYS loved the PC, but this latest brand of blind fanboyism just because some dev shows 12% more attention to the platform? I want none of it. Either a game is good because it's good, or it's bad because it's bad. THERE ARE NO OTHER QUALIFYING FACTORS. I wanted to love this game, but I couldn't even like it. 31 wasted hours. Fool me twice, CDPR.

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
6, 2016
												I only discovered The Witcher due to the extensive media buzz aroudn the third. Not wanting to leave empty handed during the Summer sales I decided to see what the buzz was and picked up the second for £2.First impressions are good, the game looks like it has a massive world and story to discover with graphics that suit the scope it aims for. It's nice to feel early on that I'm not missing out by not playing the first game, picking up the basics as I go, learning a bit about the main character Geralt as I play.For an older game the graphics are brilliant, showing Skyrim up for what period pieces should look like when money is spent wisely. The game runs at high settings on my machine, the ultra for the first time seem to run awfully, though I'm hesitant to just blame the game rather my PC showing it's limits finally. The landscapes are fantastic, big broad views and draw distance keep the world wide open. Character models look great though the voice acting sometimes drag it all down into parody territory.However the controls, combat and UI are just short of disgusting. The layout of the buttons is annoying on keyboard, using Alt to aim while trying to cycle to 'R' or 'E' to parry and press the mouse button to attack, he's not the quickest at reacting to the key presses so it becomes tiresome fast. Switch to a controller and discover the preset key bindings are barely configured, these can't be changed in game so you have to exit if you want to correct them. The fighting itself is slow and calculating, opting for a more realistic approch with two main options to fight, strong attack or light attack. Then there's powers to be used, traps/ranged attacks and an option to attack after a parry. It feels like everyone had an idea on what the Witcher fighting should be like and no ones ideas were shot down.Walking feels cumbersome and janky, it works but there's something odd about it. Perhaps it's the camera that doesn't really attempt to follow the character in any decent fashion, often gifting you the view of the back of a bush while you struggle to fit a small army. There's no jump feature either so the world has a very linear feel, restricting you to a set level.The UI is horrible at best, an entire screen filled to the brim with all kinds of options, inventorys and menus. There's no realy layout scheme that makes any sense, compared to Skyrim or other RPG's that utilise all of it's features in a nice easy to view way. Crafting, levelling up, sub levelling up and this weird power menu and another power wheel where you can take a nap or quick view your weapons all feel like over kill, you don't need to add that many features. I honestly can't be bothered to learn it all, I want to immerse myself in the world not get bogged down trying to earn my degree in Witcher menus.Overall, this is much more beautiful than Skyrim ever was and the story is engaging. However the actual gameplay drops this title into Two Worlds territory for me. Absolute ambivelance I'm happy to part with £2 for.

content:
31, 2014
												The witcher 2 is set in a fantasy medieval world inspired by polish and Russian mythology and based on Andrzej Sapkowski’s books. You play as Geralt of rivia, a witcher. Witchers are white haired mutants engineered to be professional monster slayers and are generally feared and looked down upon by regular people, Geralt uses two swords, a silver sword to fight monsters and a steel sword for humans. Because the game is a direct sequel the opening prologue puts you right into the action and new players to the series can get a little lost, however you don’t need to play the first game to fully understand what is going on, plus the witcher 2 has an extensive journal with all the information. The prologue starts off with Geralt imprisoned after being framed for assassinating the king during a siege, he’s being interrogated by the kings special forces and you play through his memories as he explains what happened during the siege. Later you manage to escape from the prison and your quest to clear your name and find out who’s really behind the series of assassinations begins. The story will take you to a number of different kingdoms and cities and you’ll meet lots of very interesting characters, how different events happen during the story is based on the decisions you make, As the story goes on the plot gets deeper and deeper, and the bigger picture becomes clearer ,who will geralt save? who will he kill? who’s side will he choose? the faith of entire kingdoms can be directly or indirectly be affected by the choices you make, the line is blurred between pure good or evil and there’s no clear morality, you do what you think is best, sometimes choosing the lesser evil in the name of the greater good, The role you play in the game has a very heavy effect on the story. The game has 16 very different endings and fully completing it will take you around 40 hours. Also i have to mention the game and story touch on drugs, murder, torture, ♥♥♥♥, incest, racism, nudity and more, however they all fit very well into the witcher universe and make the game feel very realistic and mature. If i was to compare it to a tv series it’s like game of thrones but with a richer world and with an eastern European flavour added to it.Gameplay wise the Witcher 2 is in third person and you fight in real time, combat is not easy, Geralt is not invincible and a group of knights could easily kill him if you’re not careful. Geralt can you use a number of potions and traps as well as his mutant abilities to give him an advantage in combat, potions can help him do more damage to certain monsters or improve his health, while his mutant abilities can be used to deflect arrows or stun opponents.The witcher 2 is a fantastic sequel, everything that was great about the first game has been immensely improved, the combat, the story, the characters all have been improved to a degree that is almost unbelievable, graphically it is one the best looking games ever made. The game is truly a masterpiece with a rich and detailed world, good gameplay and a deep and interesting story.

												To start with I must say that Witcher 2 is the best RPG I have ever played and one of the best games out there. It is an absolute masterpiece of a game with an awesome storyline, graphics that stay beautiful and full of detail throughout  the game, interesting characters and a fun and exhilarating combat.The story is an exceptional beauty throughout , with moral choices that effect small changes like killing a character or letting them go, and huge changes that effects the entire story and leads you on different paths and goals. the game is full of cleverly thought out and designed quests, from the wonderfully interesting main plot to side quest that'll have you finding and killing ghosts , solving crimes and if you don't want to go out and discover the mysteries beyond the walls you can stay in at the tavern and earn yourself money by gambling on fights or competing in them .  The combat can be quite challenging and can require preparation like the placement of traps, the drinking of potions that will increase weapon damage , health and many more and covering your weapons in oil and poison so the sword deals more damage and has effects. This all has to be done before combat so the player must cleverly think and path his next battle. once mastered the combat is a very fun and accelerating departure from other games combats that involves hacking and slashing by simply mashing a single button till the target is dead.The Graphics are a outstanding astonishment ( on maxed out anyway) , with an unbeatable lighting effect and texture that doesn't get poorer and poorer  the closer you get to it and focused on, the games textures stay amazing throughout . overall Witcher 2  is an incredible game and if you have a powerful enough rig it can be an amazingly beautiful one as well, with a different but fun and creative combat and a cleverly written and presented story  Witcher 2 is a master piece of a game and without a doubt is worth buying . content:
ry 20, 2014
												I bought this game for $3.99, is it worth paying that. Yeah!Some positives---1. I like the combat with the varying swords, and steel and silver depending on your opponents. Throw in some magic and it feels balanced.  The combat is better than Witcher 1.  Witcher 1 combat; some people just got fed up with the combat system in the game and stopped playing because of it, sadly missing out on the story in 1.2. I like the crafting, you have potions and sword oils to improve your combat and health perks.3. The story line is good, it flows and it keeps it's reference to Witcher 1.  4. The characters are rich with personality! Each character has their own personality.  Elves, Dwarfs, humans, mutants,  monsters have their own environments, attitudes.5. Dialog choices are pretty clear, and there are two paths you can take in the game.  It isn't entirely clear whether you are going good, evil or more evil through the game though. However the 2 paths effectively give you 2 different playthroughs, with some side missions available on one path and slight different missions on the other path.6. The environments are unique and atmospheric, and feels large enough for the game.7. It has Steam Achivements, and for me they are like an added guide to things and directions to take in the game that I might not have otherwise discovered on my own. (there are secret achievements as well)8. Merchants are great, they vary on what each sells.  However make sure you don't accidently sell the wrong thing or the buy back will be expensive (save often in case of mistakes)9. There is a primary storage location so you don't have to carry all your crap around, and it is maintained in each town as you progress through the chapters.10. Will I play it through a second time to experience the other story path? Yes!Some negatives---1. Sometimes the combat for magic is delayed even when mashing it... which causes you to die.  I did a lot of cursing! Read on a forum where one guy said to disable the enhanced features, so I did but it didn't fix it.  Maybe it's a keyboard thing? All I know is I wasn't the only one who experienced it.  And I've got a custom high end machine, and my keyboard is a G11 gaming keyboard.  Regardless the magic works on time sometimes, but not instantly another time. (it's also noted as a bug on some of the forums)2. The potion creating system can get tedious and a bit over drawn out, even picking up plants gets annoying with having to click mouse, then move mouse to yeah pick it up and then click again.  It'd be better if it was quick like ES:IV Oblivion, picking up and creating.3. No fast travel.. and I would like fast travel (I've read where people say you don't need fast travel because the environments are small enough).  Here's 2 reasons I feel it could use fast travel... 1) the running is like a jog and would be nice if it was faster so give me a sprint option!  I even searched for a way to increase run speed (like you can for FO New Vegas in the console) but couldn't find a way to increase it though.  2) the second reason I'd like fast travel is the map pretty much sucks a$$! If you don't believe me then watch this video another guy created! 


YouTube™ Video: The Witcher 2 - Why The Map System Sucks!!! 

			Views: 5,596		

			In this glorious video Renn tells you why the map system in the witcher 2 is crap. Come check out our LOVELY site - http://avidgamerreviews.com/ Go ahead and throw us a like on Facebook -...		

 4. The map sucks!!! Hire a cartographer for the mapping system, someone who understands the importance of elevations in maps! LOL  Refer to YouTube link above! When you get deep into the game, yep you'll likely start yelling like this guy does in the video listed above. I had to keep going to YouTube/Google to find certain locations... it was really annoying! And when you don't run really fast and you wind up on the other side of town and want to see if the mission is the other way you have to keep going back and forth and back and forth it's annoying! Again a sprint or fast travel would have helped! Luckily in the second playthrough having already found the locations it should be less of a headache to find places.. if I remember where they are.. LOL5. The nudity is tacky, plain and simple! LOL  Seriously the make out session with Geralt and Ves, Ves is completely naked makin' like she's banging him but Geralt still has his pants and boots on!? LOL It's a double standard plain and simple, saying it's okay to exploit women but not men. If they are going to have gratuitous sex, that will only appeal to guys who can't get laid in real life then at least make it something like they had in Dragon Age Origins.  I could do without the women are all sl_ts attitude, minus the mages who are apparently b*tches and can't be trusted in this game.6. Lastly the Quick Load could use an improvement to the programming and insert an algorithm to speed load times, so it looks for the last created quick save to load instead of reading oldest to newest file then load.  If you save a lot then later in the game your huge save folder will slow load time.  I'm a chronic saver, due to my need to explore dialog options and I accumulated 2 gig of saves in one playthrough. The slow loading can be avoided/fixed by moving a chunk of your oldest saves elsewhere if you find your quick load slowed.  This is a case where it was fast when you started the game but suddenly noticed the load times slowing, towards mid to end of the game.  If it was always slow to load then it's prolly your machine...Don't let my negatives deter you from buying.  Just be aware it's not perfect! I bought it cheap so no skin off my butt! I'd like to see a Witcher 3, but with my negatives eliminated.. LOLThere are also mods here that will enhance the game: http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/top/?

content:
, 2015
												Really, I could probably summarize Witcher 2 by saying it's an improvement over the original in almost every game-related way that matters, subjective things like atmosphere and alike being debatable, because CDPR upped their game significantly and actually worked with the engine of their own making, but that would be an easy way out and I like to complicate my life.First notable change is a clear 180 towards making the game into a more action-based installment, further enforced by removal of old combat styles and instead focusing on light and heavy attacks which give you more freedom in a sense that you can combine them on the fly without getting locked into a carefully choreographed sequences. Other than that there are changes which I would tentatively summarize as "streamlining done right" which is quite a claim in this day and age – alchemy removes the need for alcohol basis which finally lets Geralt stop being a walking cellar lugging around all kinds of high quality alcohol. It should also be noted that changes like these don't really simplify the game in any significant fashion primarily because other elements, like actual gear variety, addition of proper crafting and traps, etc easily offset whatever may have been removed.  That's not to say everything is perfect because some people had problems with the way combat works and overreliance on Quen aka protection Sign as a crutch, but I never really went through those problems so I can't testify to that.Story and characters of the game are an entirely separate beast worthy of being mentioned on their own. Witcher 2 continues after the first game, but works perfectly fine as a standalone story, although it is HIGHLY recommended that you're familiar with the original to understand who's who and what's happening in general. It retains the same old moral ambiguity and holds back no punches for the player but it's even better this time around thanks to increased world reactivity as well as choices & consequences which are really cranked up to 11. Fact that Act 2 is different depending on a choice you make previously practically guarantees at least two playthroughs to get the entire story and even then you'll still miss some modular things which can be done differently. Even though the stakes have escalated as far as the story goes, it's still a story very much grounded in reality except you now get to dabble in politics beyond just a cursory introduction.In the end Witcher 2 gets a resounding thumbs up from me. Importing your old Witcher  1 save file is also recommended. Not so much for the imported gear you'll replace fairly quickly so much as for decisions you made previously.

												The Witcher 2 is a great game where your choices matter a lot. Choices matter so much the entire second act is completely different based on who you decide to follow at the end of act 1. What's even more satisifying is that there is no black and white here, only shades of grey.Witcher 2 is rich in detail, the voice acting is terrific, the graphics are among the best and the stories and consequences of your actions are well thought out and believable. However, be warned that this is a difficult game and there's a lot of boring backtracking to do. Also, there's very little hand-holding; you'll have to listen carefully to dialogue (and read books and your journal!!!) to know what to do and where to go instead of just walking blindly to your next map marker.

content:
ry 11
												This has been probably one of the best gaming adventures I've ever had. It's hard to compare its weight, story, dialogue, character and mood with any other. It's choices are the of the weightiest I've ever had to make. The world, script and atmosphere made several of these major choices nerve-wracking for a variety of different reasons. There is no "good" path or "bad" path, it's just choice and consequence, and it's not always 100% clear what those consequences are, but the reactions and effects are fantastic to see unfold.It's improved over the Witcher 1 in every single way, and even now, years after it's release, the graphics are still downright great, the combat challenging but fun, and it still feels humble, well-acted and a solid adventure title. I would extremely recommend this to anyone looking for a good story that isn't squeamish. It's very adult, and it treats you like and adult.My cons with it would be perhaps a better tutorial, and a few other specifics like certain abilities better explained. As well as fast travel wouldn't hurt a few times. I played using keyboard+mouse and found the controls decent, though it seems to be well-made for controllers too. Overall, I had a total blast and definitely will be playing it again in the future, using a different path and different choices. Very few games I've ever played could match this for quality writing, content, script and atmosphere.

content:
, 2015
												I bought this game for $2.50 and all I can say is, wow. After purchasing the first and second games for the price of a chocolate milk, I have spent over 85 hours on the games. I really enjoyed the first one, then when I played this it blew my expectations out of the water. The story, the characters, the settings, but most of all the highly improved sword and fighting mechanics. I finally felt in control of Geralt. This game was smooth and well polished at the time of playing. Although some of the game seemed quite easy, it regularly proved to be difficult in others requiring you to think about your steps. Not challenging enough to make you give up, but enough to really involve you in the battle. Yet, this is where my one complain of the game comes up. You cannot consume any of your alchemy items or oil your blade once the fight has started. A lot of the time you may not know who you are going to fight or when. Since all consumables are timed, you don't want to always use them up. This meant sometimes saving your game, running around, loading back to the previous save to know what you should consume. I hope in the 3rd title this is changed back. Over all, amazing game. Will play through again since the story can go 2 ways. I want to see both paths that Geralt takes and am really looking forward to playing through again. Also want to see how many boobies I can convince women to show me since so far it's 100% more in this game than real life.

2015
												The Witcher 2 is one of the best action-RPGs around.  Well-written and mature story, plot, and dialogue.  The characters are well-developed. And, the decisions that you make throughout your journey changes the game dynamically.The controls are fluid, intuitive, and mapped in a style that is conducive to gameplay.  For those that are curious, I played all 60 hours of gameplay with a mouse and keyboard.Visuals are excellent for its time, and it has aged well.  Also, it is well-optimized.  My graphics and video options were set to ultra, 1200p, all maxed except for uber-sampling.  When I played The Witcher 2, I was using a GTX 670, i5-2500k.However, The Witcher 2 focuses less on monster hunting lore, and more on the political aspect of The Witcher universe.  Even then, there is some monster hunting and ghouls to fight during your downtime before you return to the game's political intrigue.If you are a fan of The Witcher books, The Witcher 1 videogame, and its universe, you owe it to yourself to play this game.  Maybe, even twice.  9.5 out of 10Highly recommended

content:
11, 2014
												This is one more of those cases like Portal where the first game felt like a real PC game and the next one feels more like a console-optimized interactive movie. (To a modest degree, but in that direction.)Yes, the production value might be high, the story might be interesting, but I'm not reviewing a movie here, but a game.While in the first Witcher game, I liked the style, all its strong points so much, I could easily overlook the various weak points, but in this game, from the very beginning, I saw little but its flaws.And because I saw way too many to edit them elegantly, here is a list of notes of the things that bothered me, in no particular order:- Dithered lighting!- Anisotropic filtering is enforced in the nVidia driver (since the game doesn't seem to have the option), but it still runs on trilinear!)In these two points the graphics in Witcher 2 are actually worse than in the first game.- Almost immediately vanishing corpses. (Same in the first game, but come on! Go with the times!)- No graphics engine or keyboard config settings in game, only via launcher. The first game had all of this.- Some fast-mouse-click QTE (quick time event) minigames are unnecessary and kind of harm immersion (sometimes practically "click now or die" - especially one scene in the prologue was annoying, since it was multi-phased and involved a sudden 180° change of camera view) - It makes little sense to expect very heightened adrenaline-pumping awareness while watching a cutscene and feels more like harassment.Even the relatively lame fist fight mechanics of the first game I found more appealing than mere WASD button pressing on command.- The precise-aim crosshair for daggers and such is almost invisible.- Some quest/dialogue progression in the prologue doesn't make much sense, i.e. leaving continuity holes- Selectable dialogue texts don't really match the Witcher's response that well. It's generally difficult to lead a conversation according to your true intention. You might end up accepting a task without wanting it. I often had to reload and try all options to at least get an idea of what I was doing.- Some dialogue barely audible because mumbled, need to reduce music volume (e.g. inn), but might be too low in other cases then.- Blood and dirt splatter on screen in cutscenes - harms immersion (4th wall breaking)- Some gold bags might be untouchable due to usable objects nearby.- An occasional geometry flicker issue that I saw in the first game, too, but no other game. Also some texture gaps.- Not being able to take a killed guard's sword during a prison break is kinda stupid, and it's not like it would be overpowered in that situation.- Game crashed before boarding a boat in one scene - couldn't save in that segment for some non-apparent reason, so had to redo and loot all the stuff I took there.- No launcher bypass possible using witcher2.exe or via other means. Launcher then places a symbol in the task bar just to add annoyance to the whole thing.- Inventory UI is kind of stupid in that it shows no stats for items in the list while highlighted, and menu items change size when highlighted, which impairs usability.- The game package doesn't even include the manual. It's just 7 MB, but I had to download it separately. Also outdated!- None of the 4 inventory sorting icons (whose meanings I had to find out by myself) gives you a value-for-weight sorting.- Inventory sorting keeps reverting to time-of-pickup.- Dropping an item from the inventory scrolls the whole list back to the top.- Key-based inventory scrolling doesn't use Windows settings. Repeat rate and trigger delay is way too high for my convenience. Also, PGUP/PGDN have no function.- Voices during conversations often have a strong reverb that doesn't match the environment at all.- A more general issue that was already in the first game: You can take stuff out of storage crates and such, and none seems to be owner-tagged, although most of it should. In a game that seeks to create immersion, this common RPG trait is always disturbing that.- Message "item cannot be sold" when trying to put it in my storage. Thus, unsellable items cannot be put in storage. Apparently the storage is just a crudely repurposed vendor.(which can lead to bugs)- Quest texts go ahead in time, telling what's gonna happen later or supposed to happen. The player doesn't seem to be considered relevant in these things and it feels like a bit of a spoiler.- Wavering camera during dice minigame is unrealistic and annoying.- Missing comparative feature of inventory item stats with worn item stats.- Fight club quest - when I'm asked to lose, I cannot decide to just quit, only accept the scam or fight (to win) anyway.- Often repeating NPC lines. Less would be more (immersive). They say the exact same thing every time you pass after an area has loaded.- Dialogue response timeouts - stupidest thing ever. For most dialogues it's perfectly fine or you to think about what to say for as long as you like (and I don't see a problem with that, and it's often necessary because the dialogue options are so unclear), but for some reason I don't see some dialogues will default to whichever option your cursor is on after a few seconds. If you don't notice the timer icon right away, you won't even know what you just chose.- When moving through the world, occasionally there's a loading symbol in the lower right corner, but loading is almost lag-free, so that icon is distracting, because when it briefly flashes, I keep thinking I just walked over a lootable object.- Geralt looks straight and not down when he's talking to a dwarf.- Small things like cursor not staying on menu when exiting to main menu with intention of selecting quit game. UI usability sucks in this game.- At least one quest didn't allow me a proper outcome in the journal and a quest tied into that one was absurdly unrealistic regarding changing a shop owner's conscience.- I am led through endless cutscenes that last long enough to let any potion run out and then right after that I'm in battle with a boss enemy, without potions. (Maybe the timers halt, but if they do, that would actually harm immersion again.)- First boss battle sucked, because while the game wants to look like a movie, the difficulty style is like hardcore indie games where you are likely to fail dozens of times, which I literally did. I must have tried 30 times. I felt like an actor and the director was shouting at me because I didn't do every move exactly according to script. I had to concentrate more on the "click now" like symbols on the screen than on the boss itself. I also at first didn't know when exactly the battle started and had to reload just to be able to drink potions in advance without wasting some of their meager 10-minute effect. Then I was frustrated because it used the wrong trap, despite me having selected the special trap for the boss. I eventually realized after several tries that I was supposed to left-click the marker with my mouse to place it. During the battle with a gigantic menacing boss, crows were sitting on a nearby corpse as if nothing was happening.- Many events could be enacted in a non-instantly-lethal way and especially in normal game mode. But instead: cutscene after cutscene. One time I was to play another character in a short event and fought someone in a duel. I fought well. The moment I defeated him... cutscene where I fail. This is disappointing and borderline insulting to the player. Don't let me fight if you intend to cheat me out of my deserved victory.Bottom line: This game often feels like it's trying to make me its trained monkey and has its fun toying with me, like I'm just an employee meant to move the story forward.A lot about this game is the same stuff that put me off about games like Castlevania LoS 1+2 (of which I played the demos).It gets surprisingly easy later-on though.- Geralt of Review

content:
er 1, 2015
												The Witcher 2: A.O.K. is a linear, chapter based story game inwhich you to decide the fate or future through the choices you make throughout your journey, that's as straight forward as it can get.Aspects of Witcher 2 Worth Praising● The Ability To Save Wherever. Sadly not many games allow you to save on your own time and it's certainly appreciated at least by me when a developer includes it. You can save anywhere when you're not in combat or a cutscene.● Unique Outlook Through Different Eyes. One unique aspect of the Witcher 2: A.O.K. is that  throughout the game you're able to play as different characters and the choices you choose with those characters greatly impacts the story.Aspects of Witcher 2 Worth Criticizing● Quick Time Events. An overwhelming majority of quests involving melee combat include this "mechanic." I've said it time and time again, quick time events are not a valid combat mechanic and only conceal the developers incompetence.● Lack of Game Funtionality. You can't swim or jump in the Witcher 2: A.O.K. and there's invisible barriers preventing you from falling or going more than knee deep in water.● Can't Rebind Particular Keys. In the Witcher 2: A.O.K. you use Mouse1 to activate doors, talk to people, light torches, fight, climb up or down ledges, and quick time events; pretty much the majority of things in this game. This is ridiculous as you constantly swing your sword or light a torch when you want to open a door.For a linear chapter based game that heavily uses cutscenes, I enjoyed traveling through the game and felt the story was an interesting experience; I'll recommend the Witcher 2. A.O.K.

content:
ry 21, 2016
												The Witcher 2 from a gaming standpoint is the meaning of the word progress, and how they improved from the first in the series. Everything from the graphics to the moving parts behind the game are an incredible feat, one you would expect from big named companies backed by a large budget. The looks of the game were not only unparalleled in 2011 due to its PC only nature, but also because it gives us a world that feels hand crafted. The attention to detail borders on the insane: the clothes, the houses and buildings, the faces of the characters, along with their weapons and in every corner, nook and cranny of the world there is that distinctive touch. The scenery is simply breathtaking, and if you're like me you will want to take a screenshot out of almost every frame. It also shows that you don't need an overabundance of browns and blood reds in your palette to show a gritty dark fantasy world. This game shows its maturity not through a pretense of adult topics or with over the top action animations, but through a careful use of its core elements and by showing the player some respect: "Yes, you're an adult, and you can handle these topics!" Because indeed the Witcher is a dark world filled with conspiracies, racism and characters who live between every single shade of gray. It is a living, breathing, unforgiving world.The story is as complex as the first , filled with twists and choices that may change the fate of many, and forking paths that make a replay of the game not only encouraged, but something you'll want to do in order to see the extent to which they occur and diverge. Normal and Hard, as easy is just that, difficulties are recommended and will test your skills if you do not face every battle with all seriousness, preparing beforehand by brewing and drinking potions and using all of your abilities during the fight. i.e. your swords, your magic signs, depending on what enemy you face and the traps and bombs for your crowd control and a little breathing room at times.The actual combat is in no way dumbed down, even if it feels less based on timing then the first. It will still punish you if you go unprepared and you can't mash your way out of battles. It is more finely tuned than in the first game, and friendly to both the use of a gamepad or mouse and keyboard. The UI is slick, easy to figure out and great looking.The ending of the game is abrupt, but one youve worked for. You might feel that it doesn't solve every issue in the game (the main storyline issues ARE resolved, though). It is no excuse from what many will consider a downbeat ending, in which it still sets up for the next in the series greatly though.  In all honesty it doesn't take away a single ounce from what this game does right, which is almost everything else. Even if you don't like the ending you will feel that the journey was worth it. There are also quite a few endings, 8 in fact, more if you consider all the side choices that could affect it.  Some are much better feeling than others, and all of which lead into the next game quite nicely.With the Witcher 2, CD Projekt RED delivered a game that is truly above and beyond any RPG from the few last years, it plays and feels like a product of love, careful planning and an overall shout to fans of the gaming community that says "We know what you want, and we can deliver. Where others have failed you we will prevail." And man did they ever. I would play this game again 5 years from now, just to remember how great a game it truly and to see how masterpiece RPGs are done.

content:
24, 2013
												Without  a doubt I would say that this game was one of the most amazing experiences I have ever had. It is challenging at times and the game refuses to hold your hand and guide you through it like a baby. It is a refreshing change of pace from games like Skyrim. It is incredibly immersive, beautiful in almost every way, and the world itself is so engaging and interesting that I was actually sad that it wasn't more open for me to explore. Combat is challenging, skill oriented, and at time not forgiving or errors. However, right off the bat the game gives you all the tools you need to succeed and as you level up you can fine tune your character to reflect your personal preferences...even if that Talent Tree could use a bit more deviation.The dialogue (and there's a lot of it) is fantastic, the allies lovable and the enemies hateable. You care about characters and persons are portrayed in a very realistic and believable way. That's the thing about the Witcher 2. It's Believable and by extension is wonderfully immersive.If you want a challenge and an immersive adventuring experience, then you need to buy this game. ---Rags' Rating - A Yummy Strawberry Cheesecake / 10

content:
er 7, 2016
												The Witcher 2 is the second game in The Witcher trilogy based on the books of the same name. Compared to the first game, TW2 improves on every single aspect. The graphics are amazing, probably one of the best in recent years. The music is great. The combat feels a lot better compared to the first game. The voice acting is also better. You can feel emotions behind the voice. The facial animation in TW2 feels real compared to the stiff faces in the first game (Zoltan's crazy eyes). The story this time takes on a larger scale which involves different sides that you can choose, meaning the choices you make in this game matter a lot.   Overall, The Witcher 2 does an amazing job serving as a sequel for the first game and as the second game in the Witcher trilogy.If you're interested in the books. I suggest reading the books first before playing the games. The games take place after the books so there are a lot of dialogues and references that spoil the events in the books. Besides, there's a satisfying feeling when you meet the characters from the books again in the games. The books order: The Last Wish -> Sword of Destiny -> Blood of Elves -> Time of Contemp -> Baptism of Fire -> The Swallow's Tower -> Lady of the Lake

content:

												It's the second game of The Witcher Franchise.  The whole game mechanics and graphics have improve greatly compared to the first game. It's beautiful looking game with a strategic combat mechanics. Yes, as an RPG game, more of the Action RPG side, it have a quality storytelling campaign with a challenging combat. You have to learn how to time your combat rather than just go with a 'typical' mob mentality. It's hard at first but rewarding along the journey. Once you get the rhythm, it will be Dark Souls like kind of enjoyment out of fighting, especially if you ramp up the difficulty. But for people who just want to play it for the stories, just choose the lower difficulty. It's no shame on choosing it, cause you do have to strategise before you enter combat with potions etc.Campaign wise, it's way wayy better that Witcher 1 for sure, and it's even have two seperate campaign after 1st chapter and its totally different set of environments/quests and you might want to replay the other side of the game later on (keep extra save games for that part). Both set line of quests offer a different agenda rather than just same old RPG style quest that make no different in the end. In Witcher 2, both side have their own agenda and it's up to you which one you like to explore. The sidequest also interesting and most of the time it's not requires too much time to be completed as it is near etc. So pick it up and enjoy the quest.Along the way, you will be presented with a lot of choices in term of how your choices affect the game storylines. The result of some choices might appear straight away or only near the end of your journey. You choose what you like, there's no definitive right or wrong. Most of the time, it's just a lesser of two evils ..... it's your choice."In Witcher's world, there's no right or wrong, only decisions and consequences."

												This definitely is Game of the Year 2011. The single best RPG I have played since Planescape: Torment. The characters are deep and complex, the storyline develops depending on your actions and choices. It takes what was good from every single RPG released in the last 15 years and makes it into something better. The graphics are simply the best ever seen in an RPG to date, if not the best that we have so far in any game (compare to Crysis if you want to). The flaws are few if any. The stealth sections are not the best, but they are optional, and there are a few bugs and such. There is no ACTUAL character customization, but you can change what the protagonist is wearing with quite a bit.The combat system works quite well. It may not be the best combat system in gaming history, but it does exactly what is is supposed to do. But all that is just beside the point. The atmosphere, the music and the character lines are just amazing, combining to create one of the best RPG's of all time.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												The Witcher 2 is one of those rare games in which you do not predict what is going to happen, one of those amazing games that, if you make the wrong decision, you will face the consequences. The thing that makes this so good is that not everything is clear, it is not black and white/paragon and renegade actions. Of my current hours (37.7), I have played within the span of 3 days. It is an addictive and excrutiatingly hard game(on dark difficulty, which I decided to start on) and while the learning curve is quite steep for begginers, it's well worth it.Alas there are a few cons to every masterpiece, for example, very little carry over from the first Witcher game (coming from a Mass Effect background) and was quite dissapointing that there were very few references to Alvin or any of the major decisions you made (eg. The scoia'tael beating on your ♥♥♥ even if you helped them in the first). Also, I finished the game without any need for the alchemy skill tree, and a lot of tasks such as building the Oathbreakers outfit is long and tedious.The lack of big bossfights were a little dissapointing and for me personally, the bosses were too easy (except that damn squid).However, the game makes up for it with breathtaking graphics (especially seeing as it is around 4 years old) and quite fluid combat, along with amazing storytelling elements and interesting plot lines. Although the lore can be boring for some and confusing for others at times as the game attempts to keep you in the dark on various matters.All in all, fantastic game.

												This review is from the perspective of a new player to the series. Yes I have “played” the first witcher but dropped it after realizing how broken the game play is.The points:+ Controller support+ Combat+ Dialog+ Characters+ Art/Level Design+ Solo+ One Ring to Rule Them all/ Lesbomancy~ Animation~ Story (my bad)~ Menus- The world- Short- Triss’s BS8/10-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Okay let's start off with the middle ground issues, the ones that were annoying but didn’t break it for me. The animation at times was great the problem is the other 50% of the time they look like ventriloquist dummies, which is worse than the Mass effect stare. The story is very hard to follow and get into the swing of understanding it however after about 3 hours in I could fully understand what was going on. The menus leave much to be desired but it’s a huge step up from witcher 1, it took about an hour to get used to after that didn’t have much issue.Now the negative, the world makes no sense I don’t understand how 8 tiny countries smaller than rhode island can pump out more then the huge southern nation. I’m sorry but these nations are conquered. The story is short like COD level game short for a RPG. And Lastly Triss’s ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, this is not a damsel in distress issue. The issue with Triss is it’s obvious by the 80% mark of the main story that ALL this time she has been lying and manipulating you, BUT NOTHING COMES OF IT. no dialog, no nothing, I’ll be starting Wild Hunt sometime today if this is not brought up I will mark that game down as well for this. Now for the good, I glad this game has controller support because rolling around using a keyboard would have been a massive pain. And it’s done very well, I have some issues with inventory but besides that everything was handled well. The combat is actually combat in this game I can sense hints of Dark Souls, which isn’t bad because this game has a better combat system then Dark Souls (no one likes a game that ques your button presses). The dialog is not Mass Effect level crap of good, funny, and mad. It’s actually a bunch of options that may lead you to what you need. The Dialog system shines best with the Golem in the mission The Secrets of Loc Muinne. The characters are properly developed and have depth to back them except for Triss(her whole character is “she wants your D” -.- not joking). The world is beautiful and the levels are large enough for the time spent in each area to make it worth it. And lastly the solo experience, this is Geralt’s story not “Geralt and his friends” story. At first I thought I would hate this, but as time went on it made you feel more awesome. Do to the fact you were doing everything on your own.

Introduction:A second chapter of the world of Geralt.Good: graphics (looks good but my eyes were bleeding in the beginning); a story line (nice trick to split it into two ways of completing the game); soundtrack (still good and not so frequent as in the first game but sometimes you lead your hero through the silence); fighting system is changing when you level up some skills; crafting system (a great variety of things available to craft); atmosphere of mid-ages battles is really impressive and you feel yourself a part of them; a strong link between games (Witcher and Witcher 2) those legendary armor and swords imported from first game were the best for a long game-play time; game stability is increased (it crashed only once for me); game saves don't take too much space anymore (comparing with The Witcher EE).Bad: an amount of side-quests is reduced (no more hidden quests you can get from some random NPC while talking. Now each active NPC is shown on mini-map); no more gifting thing (I mean in the first game you could gift some ring or something to NPC and get something for it in exchange, now all those jewelries are just a useless trash) too much bad words in the game; no more alco *parties* no more romantic *cards* (currently only porn cut-scenes :-(In total: 7 / 10P.S.: 50 hours only in total (yes, mate I completed the story once and I don't have any wish to replay it again). Sorry guys but I liked the first game more while this one is still good but not perfect.

content:
r 4, 2016
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a decision-driven fantasy RPG released by CD Projekt RED in 2011.  Like all The Witcher games, The Witcher 2 is based on The Witcher series of novels by Andrzej Sapkowski.Story (mild spoilers):The Witcher 2 (W2) takes places in a fantasy world heavy inspired by Slavic mythology and Polish history.  The universe of The Witcher games is steeped in political intrigue and features strange monsters and magical forces that influence people's lives for the better or worse.  In this world, a sect of mutant warriors called "witchers" (or hexers) serve as itinerant monster slayers for hire.  One of these witchers is the famed Geralt of Rivia, also known as the White Wolf.The game picks up shortly after the ending of The Witcher (W1), which showed Geralt of Rivia defending King Foltest of Temeria from a mysterious assassin.  In the aftermath, King Foltest "orders" Geralt of Rivia to serve as a glorified bodyguard.  However, a sinister plot by a mysterious faction compels Geralt to search for answers, reacquainting him with certain figures from his past.  Still suffering from amnesia prior to the events of W1, Geralt must regain his memories and find out who is killing the Northern Kingdoms' monarchs.W2 feels fairly shorter in story length than W1.  Nonetheless, the decision-driven storytelling of W2 remains strong, and I found the supporting cast highly memorable.  The game presents almost entirely different story paths which start near the end of Chapter 1 and dramatically change your character's quests and location for the majority of Chapter 2.  The grey morality surrounding monster slaying, philosophical issues, and political matters remains a key aspect of the decision-driven narrative.  The game ends on a bit of a cliffhanger and some plot lines seem unresolved...at least until The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.  Nonetheless, the narrative remains fairly compelling.Finally, the import system is not as comprehensive as in games like Mass Effect 1-3, but some decisions (e.g. decisions on Princess Adda, Siegfried [Order] or Yaevinn [Scoi'atel], and a couple other characters) add/change dialogue options and alter certain NPC interactions.Rating: goodGameplay:The timed attack clicks of W1 have been replaced with a more "Dark Souls"-esque combat gameplay style (if you want to use that analogy).  Geralt has a basic skill tree alongside three other skill trees for alchemy, swordsmanship, and magic.  I favored a build centered around swordsmanship with some perks in magic, but found most of the alchemy tree useless for this build.  Like in the first game, your character uses two swords: steel for humans, silver for monsters.Enemies can feel RELENTLESS early on.  You may find yourself underleveled at first, but can become a powerhouse of destruction near the end.  This unbalanced difficulty, however, may deter many players.The alchemy system of W2 does away with alcohol bases for potions in W1.  Instead, you simply combine ingredients and voila: a masterpiece.  You must have the necessary ingredients and recipes beforehand from looting and finding merchants.  Meditation is now required to consume potions, but is offset by being able to meditate almost anywhere outside of combat.  In addition, you can utilize bombs, specific sword oils, throwing knives, and traps against your aggressors.As this is a decision-driven story game, dialogue remains key to discovering info and shaping the outcome of the narrative.  You can utilize persuasion/intimidate/axii abilities to steer a conversation to your benefit provided you have the required level for each.  Be mindful that your decisions can have drastic story consequences.  This game does not hold your hand.  You are free to choose the path you believe is right.The game offers several side quests, from contracts to arm wrestling, brawling, and dice poker.  There is no fast travel, so you'll be backtracking a lot to complete these.Rating: goodAudio:I played the game in English since that's my primary language.  W2's voiceacting has certainly improved since the last game and features quality vocal talent for many NPCs.The music is AMAZING.  It is highly atmospheric and more than captures the mood and identity of each area you're in.  Some of the combat music may really get your blood flowing during fights.Rating: excellentGraphics:The game looks gorgeous, especially if you have the hardware to enjoy the lighting FX.  On high graphics settings, the environments and character models are bristling with detail.Rating: excellentOverall: I loved this game, and it certainly improves over some of The Witcher's shortcomings.  My biggest concern was the story, which felt like it was on a slightly smaller scale that that of The Witcher to me.  The cliffhanger ending is an obvious setup for The Witcher 3, but I still felt right at home playing this game.

												I love this game as much as I love my GF, it's underrated and I regret not playing it on release. It's never too late.+ Simpler, objective combat system as compared to Witcher 1.+ Superb Graphics that make you feel like its a 2013/2014 game+ Skill and problem solving oriented combat+ The true RPG, multiple choices, multiple outcomes and affects how you experience the game. + Dark mode and Insane mode is a good challenge+ Fantastic voice acting and character models+ Extremely re-playable+ Digital porn (Yes girls get naked in this game and you'll be choosing who to skoodilypoop with.)+ Realistic ambiance, Immersive and epic soundtrack/score+ Camera rotation has this blurring effect that makes combat feel even more fast paced than it already is.- Dodge heavy, making it seem like combat is about 80% dodge, 10% hit with a sword and 10% magic usage- Although it has multiple choices, it's still linear in comparison to Skyrim- Limited gear and weapons- For a powerful and legendary Witcher, you'd get your ♥♥♥ handed to you by the smallest things sometimes.- Some choices are instant deathIt's very different from Witcher 1, and I only sunk 3 hours in Witcher 1. Witcher 2, I had my first playthrough and spent 48 hours. I will be going back for more playthroughs for different choices and experience once I complete my other games that are collecting dust. This is the biggest bang for your buck during Steam sales. Trust me.
