content:
, 2015
A Paladin’s Review: Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings: Enhanced Edition: It's A Fun Time But....Plough The Lilies. Err, I Mean The Combat.Genre: 3rd Person Western RPG, In-Depth Conversation System with Combat.  Developed & Published by: CD Projekt REDPlatform Support: Windows, Mac, Linux and Consoles.Business Model: Base GameCopy purchased by myselfRead the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Preamble and DisclosureRPGs are a difficult genre of game to review. With their vast worlds to explore, hours of gameplay that measure into the 50s or 100s for a single run through and each experience guaranteed to be different, well, it can be challenging to say the least. Laying my cards on the table, I played The Witcher 2 at hard difficulty for one playthrough. I did another playthrough at normal difficulty but only got part way through. I believe those two campaigns have given me enough experience to create my thoughts for this review. The Witcher 2 was purchased on Steam by myself, two years ago. Yeah, it has been that long. So, without further ado, I present A Paladin’s Thoughts and Review of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings: Enhanced Edition. 3rd person RPG for Windows, Mac, Linux and Consoles.Overall Gameplay ThoughtsOne half of the game is having a lot of long conversations with multiple NPCs. Participating in said conversations allows for world building, acquiring side-quests, trading and/or participate in….distractions.  These are generally well fleshed out conversations and you can skip a lot of lore if you want. There’s also different conversation options that can influence the responses you’ll get. It’s not as black and white as say Mass Effect’s paragon/renegade system. Instead, it generally influences how diplomatically Geralt will approach a situation. You can also use signs or intimidation to influence the conversation to your liking, provided you’ve leveled them up enough. The other half of the game is looting materials & personal possessions from every house, building, cave and castle Geralt can get into. Right from under people’s very noses. It’s insane how often Geralt is able to just steal from nobles or kings. Hehe ok, the actual other half is the combat system. It’s a fast paced hack-and-slash system that tries to encourage tactical and quick thinking as well as planning ahead. While it is possible to avoid some fights, usually by choosing the right response or avoiding a quest altogether, it’s not possible to avoid the majority of it.Story ThoughtsMany of the characters are an unlikable lot. There are very few good guys and Geralt isn’t one of them. It feels like a lot of attention was given to Geralt, Iorveth and Vernon and the rest were mostly regulated to side arcs or doomed to two-dimensionality. Despite TW2’s attempts to subvert tropes, many characters still follow many traditional tropes and stereotypes. After all, it’s kind of hard to find characters surprising when they’re given such obvious names like Dandelion, Triss Merigold or worse: Deathmold. I mean, really? Deathmold was the best name you could up with for an evil villain? Why not just have him give us an over the top laugh when we meet him? It would have been more subtle. Everyone else is pretty easy to figure out once you meet them. They rarely stray from their outward appearance and are largely predictable. There was little attempt to justify some of the heinous acts committed by evil people. They just did it because that’s what the universe expected.The Combat SystemThe combat system seems to be designed for tactical and lethal swordplay. It rewards prepared Witchers and punishes mistakes and overconfidence. Getting yourself surrounded by the enemy will lead to a quick death while setting up traps and oils will result in a lot of dead enemies. It doesn’t help that Geralt is often outnumbered by enemies. So, he’ll need to use all of his kit in each encounter to survive. 1v1 fights are very rare in this game. Though I wish they hadn’t been. While every fight has different enemies and somewhat different attacks, I found that I had to deal with them all in basically the same way. With lots of dancing, rolling and quick poking into enemies when you can. Occasionally using a sign or bomb, hoping all the while that Geralt’s health doesn’t get nicked to death. It’s too repetitive to be ignored and towards the end of the game, well, it’s just a tiresome chore.PC Settings & Port ReportThe Witcher 2 still looks impressive after all these years. There’s a decent amount of variety in locations, character models, rich weapon & armor designs, flora, buildings, you get my point. The realistic style TW2 went for is consistent with nothing looking out of place. However, the cracks are beginning to show and I can’t ignore them. Texture quality is all over the place. Geralt and other main characters can have impressive looking armor or clothing. Take a glancing look at some other people though and you start to see some gnarly texture quality. Heck, there were some textures not far off the beaten path that looked incomplete, missing or bugged out entirely. They seemed to have a hard time keeping a consistent quality at any point, which can pull you out of the world. Worse still is the view-distance. Even at max settings, pop-in is a constant problem. Foliage being the worst offender of popping in right in front of you. Combined with character models sometimes being a bit old looking and I suspect this will lead to problems in the future. That’s if we ignore a number of animation glitches, visual clipping and others. I think that TW2 will start to age just as poorly as the first Witcher has in the coming years. It’s still not a bad looking experience for now, and a lot of these issues aren’t major, but it will add up over time.Final ThoughtsIf you’re up for a fantasy story with a solid adventure, political intrigue and interesting conversations, The Witcher 2 is certainly good for it. However, it comes with some major problems that are hard to ignore. Character’s are often two dimensional. The combat system is overly difficult and punishing even on Normal mode. Not to mention, the difficulty curve can swing wildly from fight-to-fight, especially if you install the combat overhaul mod. I’m finding it harder and harder to recommend story-based games with poor combat systems. I think it’s long overdue that devs pay equal attention to both the story & combat so that each are enjoyable to experience. I give this a very hesitant recommendation. It gets that for what the devs attempted. The Witcher 2 tried to go big and very nearly succeeded. Given more time for polish, I think this truly would have been a remarkable game. For now, it is what it is. Perhaps its sequel will be what The Witcher 2 couldn’t be.Read this Review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]A Paladin's Review: The Witcher (1): Enhanced EditionA Paladin's Review: The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt. (To Be Published)[]

content:
r 19, 2015
Review - The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition"A marvelous adventure RPG that makes you really think of what decision you should make."The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is an Adventure/Action RPG that welcomes the player once again to the world of the witcher, Geralt of Rivia. The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition starts off with Geralt being detained in dungeon as he was accused for murder of the Temerian King Foltest. He is then interrogated by Vernon Roche, the leader of the Blue Stripes, to tell his part of the story. After persuading Roche, your adventure then begins.The game has very much improved in terms of graphics and gameplay. The game's environment and atmospehere is so detailed and very engrossing that just removing the minimap can really get you lost (well, unless you have memorized the area). The soundtracks and voice actings are great. Even if you're just performing sidequests, you'll actually feel that those tasks really matter as if it's as important as the main plot of the game.One thing that sets The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings apart from other RPG games is its combat system. Geralt's swordplay is very different and unique. There will be times that hack n' slashing enemies head on could lead to your own demise.As you explore the game's world, you'll eventually come into crossroads of decisions and this is The Witcher series strong-point. Just like in the first game, your decisions really matter and affects the flow of the story, the actual ending of the quest and it even affects how the NPCs react to you. Siding with the humans can lead to elf merchants ignoring you and not giving you the service they provide. The decisions you take can either lead to death, a scar on a relationship, a new item, a battle or even a romance scene with one of the girls, etc. The player's decisions shape what kind of personality you want Geralt to portray whether you want him to be a merciful hero, a seeker of justice or just a plain old witcher doing his job.The game is quite short with having only 3 chapters (4 in all if you include the prologue) but its immense design on each quest makes the game very long. After your first playthrough, it'll make you want to start all over again as you'll wonder what would have happened if I made this decision instead of the other.The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a totally great game that once you finish it, you'll end up looking for more of it. I highly recommend this game to big fans of the Witcher series and to those who really love Action/Adventure RPG games with great story content.Personal Rating:Story/Plot: 9/10Gameplay: 8/10Music: 9/10Grapchics: 8/10Overall: 8.5/10

content:
er 25, 2013
												The Witcher 2 is a game with memorable characters, beautiful towns and landscapes, and a story filled with political intrigue. It's rare to come across a game with choices which feel impactful while avoiding typical 'black and white' or 'good and evil' situations. What lacks in gameplay is made up through the narrative.The gameplay is sub-par. Geralt of Rivia is equipped with two swords: one for human-slaying and one for monster-slaying. With magic-like abilities called signs to go along with his swordplay, Geralt is a force to be reckoned with. Dodging and parrying are two important aspects of the combat system. Geralt can die in a moment's notice if the player isn't careful, so it's vital to know when to be aggressive or defensive. However, The combat feels sluggish. The tab-targeting feels unresponsive at times, dodging does not always go the way the players want it to, and contact with enemy units does not feel responsive. A huge plus though is the way a player has to prepare for each encounter. Geralt cannot use potions during combat, only when he is meditating, which a player can do at anytime outside of combat. Potions range from boosting his recovery rates to increasing his attributes and resistances. It's a fairly comprehensive system and adds a layer often missing from other games.To level up, the player is given a 'skill tree' to add attribute points to four different categories, each composing of their own active and passive skills: Training, Alchemy, Signs, and Swordsmanship. The leveling up system is not complicated, but the choices you make are important. Geralt can level up to 35, which for example can fill up  the Training Tree and one other. So the player is given the choice of specializing in a certain tree, or become a jack-of-all-trades, balancing their skills points across all areas. It's a simple system which relies on player choice as a main driving force.The story is interesting enough to continue unraveling its many mysteries. Geralt meets friends, foes, and backstabbers along the way. What's great is that each character has a sensible motive to their actions. Voice-acting is great and the writing is well-done. The cutscenes do not offer much in terms of action, but the dialogue options and the strive to know more about the characters is enough to justify the more static encounters. Visually the game is absolutely beautiful. The lighting was and still is the best in the gaming industry. It benefits to take a second and marvel at the scenery surrounding Geralt. The forest around Flotsam, the first town Geralt encounters, is stunning. It helps make the world come alive, and like Mass Effect, creates a very convincing world, as if there's a lot more going on than what Geralt sees in his eyes. The character models, although great, could use some variety. It was common to come across the same character models across various parts of the game.If you are a fan of mature-themed RPG adventure, this game ranks among the best of them. It comes highly recommended.

												Drawing from it's rich source material the Witcher 2, continues the tale of Geralt of Rivia as he seeks to uncover the truth behind a mysterious group of assassins who are after royal blood. Building on the amazing story which started with the first Witcher game, considered a classic by many, Witcher 2 also improves the experience of being a professional monster-slayer. The combat is challenging and realistic ( no chugging fifty potions in the middle of a fight :P ) and the visuals and voice acting are excellent, and the story as aforementioned is gripping filled with impactful choices, characters that you will grow to love and others whom you'll want to introduce to a witcher's blade.  For those who have played the Witcher 3 Wild Hunt and want to immerse yourself more in the witcher world but find the first witcher to have not aged particularly well Witcher 2 Assassins of KIngs is an excellent game detailing Geralt's adventures leading upto the events of Wild Hunt. Overall an amazing RPG and good entry point for those who have never played a Witcher game as well as returning monster-slayers.

er 7, 2016
												A good game, but not a perfect game. The atmosphere, the graphics, the idea behind the game are wonderful.  As are many of the characters, even the character you play is quite amazing himself. It's an immerssive game that captures the player and throws lots of enemies at you and lots of very neat little details. This game, based on the books definately does feel like an RPG. The gameplay is relatively satisfying, with visuals probably outdoing the gameplay itself but they create a very uniqe atmosphere which I prefer to other RPGs.In this game the choices actually do matter, there's quite a few and it's not just black or white (morally speaking). What is also unbelivably suprising about TW2 is that, despite the game coming out in 2011. This game on Ultra looks still up to date as ever, it looks astonishing truely.While this game succeeds in delivering a good RPG experience, there are some issues which don't make it a 10.. - The saving game system is far from perfect, not allowing you to save over games or choose the name of your saves instead every time you save it creates a new save. Doing this can make a huge cluster of saves which freeze your game every time you click load. So you must periodically clean old saves.- 3 big skill trees to pick from but very few skill points make it quite difficult to build the ultimate Witcher. - The game is actually quite short, especially if you don't do the side quests. Of course, after this there is the Witcher 3 which only continues the best kind of fun. The amount of hours I have are not correct, as I tried to play this game before but never completed it so it's more hours than needs be. - The facial animations are subpar, not really great at showing off emotions of the characters.- The combat is unforgiving at the begining, defiantely needs getting used to and remember Space is your friend.

content:
5, 2016
												The Witcher 2 EE is like your neighborhood cougar. A fine woman who's grown wise through her experiences. Seductive in her gaze, can treat you to a good time then read you a bedtime story. (Compares a computer game to an attractive woman.... descending ever deeper and deeper, are we?)Right, Right...... The Witcher 2.An essential chapter in The Witcher video game trilogy. Unlike the original game from 2007, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is an absolute must for those interested in playing it's sequel, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. The state of the Northern Realms in the third game is a direct outcome of major events that transpired over the course of Assassins of Kings. The Witcher 2 continues the tale of an amnesia-struck Geralt of Rivia. After foiling an assassination attempt on King Foltest's life, the legendary monster slayer turned royal bodyguard must accompany Temeria's king into battle against traitors of the realm. As stated, a player need not play the original for an enjoyable experience, but for those who prefer complete participation, emotional investment, and absolute understanding of its references and characters, it is advised. Positives:  - Stellar choice-driven narrative. - Immersive gameplay mechanics. - Soundtrack is brilliantly enveloped around a player's every action; electrifying during combat yet sentimental when required. - Believable fictional world brimming with interesting interactable characters. - Stunning visuals. (Dem textures doe!!!!) - Punishing difficulty that forces players to use all the tools at their disposal. - Pixilated tittays! ...in your face literally a few minutes after you start the game.Negatives (More like knit-picks):  - Conversation persists even when paused by the player. - Geralt's Grayish silver hair rather than the lore-appropriate milky white. (Easily corrected with a mod) - Glitch where unlooted items from fallen enemies disappear after reloading a save.  - Geralt's movement constantly interrupted by invisible surfaces belonging to furniture and vegetation. So F*ckn good, y'all don't even know.

content:
18, 2015
												I bought this game years ago... when I played it the first time I didn't like it tried another five times still no dice. Now I'm here don't know what changed maybe I just didn't understand it but I'm glad I gave it a shot, better later than never right?So let's get all the good stuff out of the way first, the biggest and greatest change has to be the combat it's fast paced full of action and well it just feels great. The game looks good and has aged well, has a tonne of options to mess with too always a plus. The keyboard and mouse work great but default key binds feel odd and a controller works perfectly. The audio is amazing from the voice acting to the sound effects all the way up to the soundtrack. I would say the game length is good took me roughly about 30-35 hours to complete, there's also a tonne of side quests to do and of course heaps of main quests. The user interface is great with a mouse and keyboard but a bit weird with a controller still works fine though. There's some great game changing choices to be made and that's to be expected from a heavily story driven game. It also comes with a arena mode it's as fun as you'd expect from a survival based mode but it's still a great pass time.Now the bad... first thing I want to get of my chest is the navigation I don't think I have ever played a game with such a detailed but useless map and mini map, I found myself getting lost often because of it. There is no sprinting and at first it's fine but later you'll find yourself pulling out a sword just to dodge everywhere. A downside to the new combat is once you corner a single enemy excluding main bosses they get stuck and can't fight back, small gripe which made it feel cheap. The games pacing feels off most of the time, sometimes it's quick sometimes it's slow other times it's super quick etc it never seemed subtle. There doesn't seem to be enough different armor and weapons to go collect and spend time on, which is fine I suppose but I excepted more. A minor bug I found on dual screens was an invisible second mouse pointer would appear on the second screen hovering over things, not a big deal but annoying.I honestly think the game is great if you are craving a story driven game, it might not appeal to some but it's definitely up there with the Mass Effect series.

content:
, 2015
												The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings is by far one of the best RPG's ever made.      I will attempt to explain the why in my review. I will cover all levels of thegame, graphics, story, combat etc.      I will start off with the story that is being told. As someone who loves adeep immersive story and world this game is a delight. The characters areall well voiced and feel like they have a lot invested in the world as wellas them not appearing to be cardboard cut outs just conveying the nextplot entry to the player. You have to make choices in the Witcher 2. Whichfor those of you who played the first will find a bit urking if you enjoyed taking the Witcher path (neutrality). However the stakes are greatly raisedin the sequel. The fate of the entire northern realm is being decided and your choices as Geralt will have long term ramifications on the world.      This is the only game I have ever had to sit back, get up out of mychair and weigh the pros and cons of my decision. I have never feltmore invested in a series than the Witcher series. It is such a believable world, so well crafted with so much attention to detail and love it is unmissable. The story is exciting, if it does feel over a bit too soon. Inmy 2nd playthrough I played on normal, did just about everything youcould do with some additional grinding out levels etc and that took meabout 45 hours. Where as my Witcher 1 play through took me 60+. That being said the enhanced edition of the game that I played for thefirst time since the games original launch has added a lot of contentand interesting things that make the game a bit more fleshed out togive players a bit more of a satisfying conclusion leading up to the third game.     The graphics to be honest are still the best we have seen on the PC.I believe that if they released a brand new game (story, combat etc)with the existing engine everyone would still be blown away. The factthat CD Projekt said "Nah its not good enough" and created a newengine for the Witcher 3 is insane especially by todays standard oflazy ♥♥♥ developers copy and pastaing as many god damn games asthey can to meet their annual release schedule (♥♥♥♥ you Call of Dutyand Battlefield) is a breath of fresh air in a stagnant market. I boughta 980 superclocked for the Witcher 3, and I can't even run Witcher 2with ubersampling (I don't even think it does anything other than cater to the egos of nerds with quad titan blacks) but other than thatI can ultra this game at 80-100 FPS constantly at 1080p. The gameis absolutely beautiful, the textures the character models. Everythingis picture esque. It is the exact thing we pc gamers love to see. Detail.     Now onto Combat. As a fan of the original games fighting style alaJedi Knight esque "stances" combat which I know a lot of people hatebecause it can come down to just button clicking at the right time. Iinitially hated the Witcher 2 combat, it was sluggish and felt ratherconsolized. After 4 years passed I picked the game up again now thatthe enhanced edition has improved combat it feels much more responsive and fun. Even if it still feels to be a bit of a "Roll fest". Ido feel that combat still needs improvements to make it more interesting, a hybrid of one and twos combat systems could workout incredibly well and make the game feel unique in its own right. That being said the combat has been improved and I have heardthere are mods that made the combat even better.      I have a lot of love for this game and for this series. I think thatCD Projekt red has proved themselves among the best developersof games to this day. Their mentality is that of the days of old. When people who loved games, made games. It wasn't a dayto day job. It was done with passion and commitment. You can tell CD loves their IP, and their franchise. Their commitmentto their fans has been something truly admirable. They givefree content out that most companies would charge a boat loadfor. Most of you would say "Well that's nothing special they shoulddo that anyway" I agree with you in theory but that is not the point. The point is they do not HAVE TO, but they DO. They care about the people who play their games. That is why I love them and am eagerly awaiting The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt. This game is a must if you love RPG's. It is an absolute must.9/10

content:
, 2012
												The Witcher 2: Assassin's of Kings is not only one of the finest RPGs but also one of the best games ever made. It boasts an insanely amazing intellectual mature non-linear driven story made by your own choices, and it lives up to it's word. Very well written, memorable characters, some dam amazing dialogue and very well structured. One has to play this at least twice to realize/understand the entire game as every playthrough will have something different to offer. And this is with no doubt THE best looking game out there (until The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt comes out), real feast for the eye.For fans of RPGs and rich complex story telling, this is a must play.My full review: http://expedition-megacosm.blogspot.in/2012/05/witcher-2-assassins-of-kings-enhanced.html

content:
ry 6, 2016
												Drawing from it's rich source material the Witcher 2, continues the tale of Geralt of Rivia as he seeks to uncover the truth behind a mysterious group of assassins who are after royal blood. Building on the amazing story which started with the first Witcher game, considered a classic by many, Witcher 2 also improves the experience of being a professional monster-slayer. The combat is challenging and realistic ( no chugging fifty potions in the middle of a fight :P ) and the visuals and voice acting are excellent, and the story as aforementioned is gripping filled with impactful choices, characters that you will grow to love and others whom you'll want to introduce to a witcher's blade.  For those who have played the Witcher 3 Wild Hunt and want to immerse yourself more in the witcher world but find the first witcher to have not aged particularly well Witcher 2 Assassins of KIngs is an excellent game detailing Geralt's adventures leading upto the events of Wild Hunt. Overall an amazing RPG and good entry point for those who have never played a Witcher game as well as returning monster-slayers.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21
												Although 'The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings' happens to be my least favourite game in the trilogy, I still found it very enjoyable. It begins with a very exciting introduction, and the new combat system is well-explained in the opening quests. Also rather early in the game we meet the antagonist of 'Assassins of Kings'.My favourite of all the 'Witcher' villains is from this second instalment: Letho of Gulet. Letho is a man of colossal proportions, and matches his incredible power with a sharp, cunning mind. Some of the other characters introduced in this game are also rather memorable, but none so much as Letho. The perfectly written villain is just one element of a very good story.These days, we're all familiar with RPGs offering players a choice. We were also very familiar with this feature five years ago when this game released. Still, none of the games I've played have offered a choice quite as significant as one of the ones presented in this game, in which your selection will change at least 6-8 hours of gameplay.I wish this game had been as open to explore as the other 'Witcher' games, and I think more investment in side quests could have been made. Still, play 'Assassins of Kings' and you'll be signing up for a first-rate fantasy adventure, full of highly entertaining battles and well-written, well-acted characters.

content:
7, 2014
												It's a great game.  As in Witcher 1, your choices matter.  When it was released the graphics were next-gen, but it was nearly unplayable on my system due to bugs.  Here we are years later with the Enhanced edition for which I am playing it through a second time, and there are still bugs.  Nothing game breaking, but highly annoying nonetheless.It's still a great RPG with an intriguing story, though I am betting you'd appreciate it more by reading the books, which I have not read.  Gameplay wise, it can sometimes be a little hack and slashy, but on the higher difficulties you're forced to use a bit of strategy; it differs a good bit from Witcher 1 and takes a little getting used to.  If you're an RPG fan it's not one to miss, but you really should play the games in order to know what's going on (I actually like the 1st more than the 2nd in a few ways).

content:
er 30, 2014
												The game's a masterpiece. It's pushing bounderies on how a sword fighting game can be handled. I haven't played another game that so well binds melee fighting with alchemy and sorcery. The three and like the legs of a tripod for successfull advancing in Witcher 2. It's also one of the hardest games out there, mistakes in battle are unforgiving and depending on what choices you make you can have 2 completely different playing experiences. Below are some pros and cons:Pros+ The game is unique in many features.+ You actually need to combine magic, alchemy and fighting to be successful.+ Geralt is more of a brute and not such a playboy as he was in the first game.+ The difficulty of this game is way beyond your usual RPG.+ Water looks the best I’ve seen anywhere in games + Might be the most tactical swordfighting game. Bombs, signs, traps, oils, potions + the right weapon - there's so much to take into account before going to battle.+ Complex and interesting story with memorable characters.Cons- Under Mac the game crashes on reload almost every time. The game crashes a lot under Windows as well but much less than under Mac.- Mac issue: whereas the game doesn’t take that long to load, it takes ages for the load screen to come up.- Poor optimizing of graphics. With max settings the game is an artistic masterpiece, yet it takes a great computer to run full graphics. For some reason Witcher looks a little better in Windows than in Mac. - Looting takes time and precision.- The game get's easier as you play, a lot easier. Also, the gaps between difficulties are extremely jumpy, going fromdying in 10 seconds to not getting a scratch.- The city of Vergen was a navigational nightmare, a maze in it's worst form.- There's a weird delay at the end of the sword swinging move that starts to feel painful in battles, especially when you wanna hit and dodge. Verdict:I highly recommend this game, it's a positive challenge and highly original. There were few things that bugged me, most of them had to do with optimization, but I'm completely ready to forgive them all for the outstanding work of art that was built.

content:
ry 22, 2015
Time of completion: ~21 hours (68 days total)Date of writing the review: 22.February.2015Difficulty I played at: Easy (with a little twist, read below for more info)My rating: 7.5/10=====================================My review will be separated into different parts covering the many different aspects of the game. First let me give you my overall opinion and if you want you can read about every small detail about it.This game is great, I loved it. Unfortunately it suffers from many design flaws, which really make your experience frustrating at times. It seems that the developers didn't learn their lesson too well from the previous game's problems. I had to stop playing for about a month because of how the missions were layed out and the unclear mission markers.I played it on EASY difficulty, but only used the armor I imported from my "The Witcher 1" save and that armor sucks. I did not use trophies or good trousers or gauntlets. This really gave me a challenge and made the game a lot more enjoyable. Graphics and performance  I played it on a PC with an i7 4770, GTX 770 and 8GB ram on MAX settings. The performance was perfect. Stable 60 fps in every part of the game. It only dipped to 40-45 fps while exiting out of a cutscene, but it wasn't for more than 3 seconds anyway.The loading times are way too long though. The one that really stands out is when you die. After dying it takes a huuuge amout of time for the "reload" text to appear, staying in a black screen for more that 10 seconds. That forced me to constantly quick save so I don't die and have to wait for the black screen to disappear, I reloaded the save before the final blow.The graphics at first felt very weird to me. The whole prologue has this yellow overlay and makes the scenery look cartoony and fake. After the prologue is over the graphics look just right. Lots of greenery, beautiful scenery and an amazing view. Story:   I had no trouble understanding the story of "The Witcher 1", but this one was too much for me. I found it very difficult to follow. I often asked myself: Why does this guy do this ? Why is this here ? Why can't I just do this instead of this and all our troubles will be gone? The multiple choices were great though because I didn't like certain characters in the game and I wanted to see them suffer. Choosing to kill someone instead of saving them gave me the feel that I am in control of Gerald's life and I am not just there for the ride. This opens up the option to replay the game and have a different experience. I will definitely replay the game again in the future. Combat system A HUGE improvement over the combat system in The Witcher 1 in my opinion. There is just so much more to do than just mashing the left mouse button. You can dodge, parry, set traps, use mutagens to increase your abilities, meditate to drink potions and more. Unfortunately some of these options are completely unnecessary. I never once used a trap and never threw a dagger at someone's face.The meditation system is terribly implemented. In order to drink a potion (something which will decide the outcome of the battle) you have to meditate. You can only meditate before a battle and not during it. Then how the hell am I supposed to know when exactly a battle is gonna start ? How can I know when to prepare ? I know it looks more realistic this way, but in my opinion the game suffers because of it. This forced me to constantly quicksave after moving 20 meters because I didn't know when a battle wound start. Controls: The controls are not bad, what annoys me is that one key is used for so many actions. For instance the left mouse button is used to: attack, put out fires, jump down, climb up, talk, open doors and pick up items. I play on a PC, I should have the option to choose, not to have everything on the same key. I often picked up items I didn't want instead of opening a door, or climbed down a ledge instead of picking up an item. This adds to the frustration I mentioned earlier. Freedom: ... or the lack there of. There is not much freedom in movement. The Witcher 1 suffered from this too. The world is big, but it doesn't feel big at all. There is a pre-determined path you have to walk on. What if I want to go behind this house, or go and see this bush up close ? I can't. The world is very limited in terms of where you can go. Another thing is the ledges. I can't jump down from a half a meter tall ledge without clicking the left mouse button and waiting for Gerald to align himself to the exact spot where he can jump down and wait for an animation. I cannot just jump down from anywhere, no, I have to find the ledge where it says: jump down and then click on it. both TW1 and TW2 suffer from this and really slow down the game play a lot. Speaking of that... Gameplay: This is a story-driven game and unfortunately the gameplay will be constantly interrupted by a cutscene. I swear the cutscenes are so abundant that you can't walk 50 meters before being interrupted by a villager or a dwarf wanting to arm wrestle me. Not much gameplay to be had here. Fortunately the battles and especially the boss battles are very well made and some take a long time to complete without an interruption. Length: I was really surprised by how short the game felt. That must be because about 40% of the game is cutscenes or dialogue. If felt really short. Even after replaying the first 2 hours, starting from scratch, completing the game, spending an hour or 2 on arena mode, the game still felt very short for some reason. I mean it's 2 times shorter than The Witcher 1 and that game did not have so many cutscenes. ( 39 hours in TW1, 21 hours in TW2). Side missions: While the first game had very lengthy side mission, which made sence and gave you great benefits after completing them, this one  has none of that. Most (maybe 80%) of the side missions consist of: kill X number of enemies in this area and bring me proof, or win X number of arm wrestling contests, or win X number of dice poker games. Speaking of which, dice poker was my favorite distraction in TW1, in this one the dice are way too dark and hard to see, the symbols on them are almost identical, so I avoided playing it, that's unfortunate because I really loved that mini-game in TW1. Other small nit-picky things, which didn't fit anywhere else: + Boobs: You will see boobs, lots and lots of boobs. You will see and touch at least 5 pairs of boobs, if you search for them, you might get to see even 10 pairs.- Mission markers: Very difficult to determine where exactly they are. Often you will be standing on one, only to figure out that it is several floors below you. Now you have to find another way to get to it. Even games from 2002 had mission markers that indicated if the objective is above of below you and actually made sense (GTA Vice City)- Vergen: There is this city in Chapter 2 that has the worst layout ever. I am willing to bet that about an hour and a half of my playtime was spent trying to figure out how to get to a lower lever or find where exactly the mission marker is located. This chapter made me stop playing for about a month because of how annoying the layout of the city was.=================================================There is more to talk about, but I will leave it here because I ran out of characters. If you have questions then ask away, I will answer everybody. That's it for the review, I recommend the game, I paid 4 euro for it on the summer sale, but would not buy it for full price. The game definitely does not deserve the "best RPG ever" award and does not even come close to it. It is highly overrated and does not deserve a score higher than 7.5/10.Please play The Witcher 1 first, it was incredible and this one is a downgrade from the original.

												An excellent rpg with great soundtrack and dark humour where your choices does make a difference. The game has pretty interesting lore. I suggest you play the first game or read the books to have a better understanding of the story. The graphics were pretty good for an 2012 game. I find that their dialogues can be quite humourous at times. Be warned however, as this game's combat system punishes those who rush into the fight without preparation. Use everything in your arsenal including potions, spells, equipments and buffs to fight your enemies. The only problem with this game is that it always crashes when you have a lot of saves. All in all, I'd give it a solid 9/10.Glad I spent money on such a dedicated team. Look up CD PROJEKT ;)

												I don't do reviews often (that's my friend HOTSHOT's job and specialty, hehe) but this game really deserves one from me.Simply one of the best RPGs I have ever played in my entire life. Amazing story (follow-up to The Witcher 1 in some ways but with a few new twists in the plot), awesome gameplay and really memorable characters. Keep in mind that the game has a bit of a "steep" learning curve when it comes to the combat mechanics. You really need to kind of "study" and pay attention to your enemies' moves/patterns (sort of like Dark Souls but not near as difficult) because you die pretty quickly, even on Normal difficulty.You need to get this game, even if you don't like RPGs, just the story itself is so compelling that you will have the desire to finish the game just to see how it unfolds. Buy it. Buy it. Buy it.

												This game is about our beloved witcher, Geralt of Rivia. Join him on an epic journey to clean his name and help the kingdom from falling apart. This is a game where your choices will have some affect on the later parts of the game. The games about The Witcher are very story-driven, so I would recommend you to read or play through the first "The Witcher". The combat is fun, and not only Hack and Slash, so it is challenging, and after some fights you will need to combine attacks with potions, poisons and Signs, magic spells Witchers use. The story is great, and after a while you will find out that Geralt is a character with great depth and a incredible backstory. If you want a monsterslaying game, a game with good story and atmosphere or just a game with good combat, this game is for you.

content:
ry 14, 2014
												Witcher 2's great in all fronts, graphics, gameplay, story, lore, charecters and so on. The action-RPG's a unique one, having been developed by CDProjekt Red, a Polish dev company bringing us a real prideful offering as to how a western action-RPG presents itself on the global stage. Unique in what regards?Positive:W2 has plenty of choices in the story arc, even outside the main forks in the road such as Roche's path, or Iorveth's path, there's certianly multiple ways to handel meeting up with bosses, and other key plot points. There's ways to close/not initiate certian mission b/c of xyz, so I sugest watching the "Changing Locations" vid from the devs on the multiple stories. W2 is indeed practically 1.5 games in 1.  The dialogue trees fill a convergence in the emersiveness and gets away with some pecilular takes on the cast's rogueish attitudes, Geralt picking up on chicks, the dice minigame, midevil slang, such as bugger, wh0r3son, ba$tard, all terms you don't really hear in the modern Americas, but used in Scottland, the UK, and such, however b/c this is a myere'd and dark time, synergysticaly it all plays to the story. Negative:The combat can be handled via simple mash to progress, however if you get into the rolling and dodgeing, you can fine tune your fighting tactics. Geralt's the archetypical battlemage w/ rather straightforward skilltrees for wizardry, and alchemy, however his swordplay and dodgeing whilst in combat are his coup de' grass. The skilltree progressions are linear, un-complicated, and arguabley a bit of a toss. Wizardy allows you to throw spells at a one shot per meter rate in battle, giving enemies status effects such as catching fire, while the alchemy tree has you crafting interesting potions that, unfortunately, can only be used just before the battle commences. The weapon/armor progression system's unique in an unfavorable way in regards to the story's tendancy to branch meaning you can miss a NPC needed that would have given you quests, or items, or even find yourself in custody, or in a dundgeon, and if you didn't explore it just right, you will lose your confiscated gear.W2's submenu's and UI are still difficult to nagivage, and aren't user friendly, however they're mods to it.Witcher 2 has a modding community as well, w/ game dev's even adding to the combat w/ advances from Witcher 3. Witcher 2 Multiple Paths Trailer: "Changing Locations"http://www.gametrailers.com/videos/1utzna/the-witcher-2--assassins-of-kings-enhanced-edition-exclusive-changing-locations-trailerWitcher 2 Offical Dev's "Unofficial Combat Mod" w/ aspects in combat from the upcoming Witcher 3http://redkit.cdprojektred.com/index.php?c=mod&m=show&p=77

er 20, 2016
												I understand why people love this game—I get it, it has fantastic graphics, a great story, wonderful music and characters—so much to love. But what in the liviing hell is up with the terrible menus and AWFUL controls?! "Oh, I see I'm surrounded, better roll around and make sure to attack in the direction I'm facing"*Geralt attacks blindly in opposite direction while getting hacked in the backWhy can I not look at the key bindings in-game?Why can I not adjust the graphic settings in-game?Why does Geralt REFUSE to attack the guy with the shield who is on his &$#*ing KNEES?! He's right there, Geralt, it doesn't take a #$*ing witcher to NOT swing your bloody sword over his head, or for some unknown ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ reason turn your back to him while attacking in the general direction of the camera.I want to love this game. I love everything else about it. But without something resembling competent gameplay, a game is NOTHING to me. If the gameplay and UI were any clunkier, it would a box of rocks (that you pick up with the same button as attack, because yes, the gameplay here makes THAT little sense).This game isn't hard (I think I'm one of the few people who thought Dark Souls 2 was too easy), but I feel like I'm being punished by simply playing the game.What a massive dissapointment.**I am still going to try to get into this game (again), and if my opinion changes I'll update, but this is now my third time, and I still hate the combat in this game.

												Easily the best RPG I have played in years.A rich and vivid world that is home to a story that defies typical fantasy cliches. It's a story of complex political intrigue and not the same old good versus evil hogwash.  A rather challenging real time combat system plus the gorgeous graphics make this one of the overall most complete experiences of 2011.Every RPG fan must play this and people that just like a good story as well as graphics freaks will also get their moneys worth out of this for sure.LINUX Port warning (June 2014): Currently the port suffers from abysmal performance issues and quite a number of stability problems due to it being made by a company that used a wrapper instead of porting it native. Sale discounts leave the game at around 4€ which might be worth the gamble.

content:
er 29, 2011
												The Witcher 2 is not an RPG for the faint of heart. It will NOT cater to your needs - do not expect it to be easy, or lighthearted, or something to play when you have nothing better to do. It expects you to be Geralt of Rivia, the world's greatest witcher, and you WILL be him or GAME OVER trying. My advice: get a week's supply of popcorn and coke, lock the door to your room to keep out everyone in order to be able to get absolute peace and quiet, and press the PLAY button and disconnect yourself altogether from real life. Allow the living, mysterious world of Andrzej Sapkowski's work to devour you, wasting innumerable hours of your time. The story is incredibly well-written: only in this game is a character who barely survives half the act portrayed as few companies manage to portray characters in a whole frickin' game's plotline. Become the Witcher: it certainly couldn't be simpler.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												Before we proceed, understand that I actually like the gameplay in The Witcher 2. In fact, it's exceptional. Combat is easy to play yet hard to master – an elusive quality in action RPG combat mechanics – with plenty of difficulty and interesting combat scenarios. By the end of the incredibly well put-together tutorial, you'll feel like you honestly participated in medieval siege. A rich and complex crafting system underpins plenty of gameplay interactions and makes many of the incidental bits of junk you collect through the game have real value. And on top of all of this, The Witcher 2 is one of those rare RPGs that flirts with having real consequence to player decisions throughout the dialogue.Thus, I feel I have to give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings a good review score; by every objective standard of game design, development, and production values, it is an excellent game. I cannot recommend it unreservedly, however, as a few things about the game never quite clicked into place for me. I found myself, at the end of it, more stricken by some of the evident gaps in story and gameplay direction than enthusiastic for the inevitable sequel that, presumably, will tie together the numerous loose ends of the storyline.The first Witcher was a game that I had a very hard time playing through. On the one hand, I loved the writing and variety of choice available throughout the dialogue and intrigue portions of the game; on the other hand, most of the momentary gameplay was painfully overcomplicated and obtuse. Any game requiring that I explicitly enter combat mode and then explicitly choose a stance before I can start wailing on dudes loses points in my book. The Witcher 2 eschews many of the more glaring flaws of the original game—a more streamlined UI, a closer camera so you can really see what's going on, and a combat system that emphasizes skill are all welcome additions to the series.There are some distinct flaws in the gameplay, though nothing major. The first and most obvious one is how side quest objectives are communicated. The Witcher 2 has joined the slew of recent games that basically lead you through the objectives to complete side quests (and, actually, main quests) by hand. While I have some objections to that in general, my complaint in this case is more about some of the little gaffes in how that's presented.The next major flaw in the gameplay is that autosaving is used in the game, but not always in intelligent ways. At some boss fights, the game will autosave right before the big introduction cut-scene of the boss. This makes sense if you walk away from the game for a few days after dying to the monster once; but if you're like me, and try again... several times... then needing to blunder through the cut-scene time and again becomes a real nuisance.The third major flaw is that there are unique gameplay modes – such as stealth – which will activate contextually, but you are explicitly told to enter them. Since the game decides when you enter into the mode, why are you telling me to go into the mode? What button is that? Not a big deal by any means, but a little irritation all the same.Graphically and aurally, the Witcher 2 is a very well put-together game. Lush visuals, fantastic texture work, great visual effects, and clear iconography keep the game attractive. The music is, by and large, very fitting, and the sound design tactfully places you in the middle of the events of the game. Lots of nice little touches – folks chopping away at wood in a little village, the crumbling of nearby rocks as you climb down a cliff face, or the occasional snap of twigs as you tromp through the forest – pop out of the speakers regularly. Voice acting is also quite good. I think I take the most issue with the writing and character design. By and large, the Witcher series has a very dim view of most people. Just about everyone is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in The Witcher 2; even Geralt's sorceress girlfriend, the character who the writers tried hardest to make sympathetic, comes off as a catty, jealous ♥♥♥♥♥ at times. It's not that I believe people are always nice and friendly, but when there's not a single decent person to talk to, it gets hard to take any of the characters seriously.The other side of this is that some of the best written, most charismatic and genuinely fun characters to be around don't last terribly long. This is made abundantly clear by the end of the tutorial. Apparently in Witcher world, fun people aren't fit to live.By the end of the game, I found myself left with a distinctly ashen taste in my mouth; the victories are left hollow and incomplete. Partially because the ending doesn't fully resolve the numerous sub-plots of the game, but also because the storyline felt arbitrary and disconnected. The Witcher's style – weirdly dark and artificially edgy, especially for a fantasy title – creates disjointed storylines that, even when the promised ending occurs, are a letdown.I also might mention that The Witcher 2 represents a... particular view of women. If you are comfortable seeing women portrayed as little more than ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥, then this is the game for you! If, on the other hand, you find the lack of strong female characters in games to be irritating, then this really isn't for you. Triss and Ves, two of the notable female characters of the game, don't count, by the way; both spend most of their screen-time in form-fitting outfits, prancing their overly shapely asses about the focus point of the camera and generally requiring Geralt's manly help to accomplish much of anything.Despite all the little flaws and caveats, The Witcher 2 is, ultimately, a fantastic game; any fan of darker, more consequentialist fiction will find themselves right at home. Nevertheless, those of you looking for something more upbeat, more uplifting – and frankly, less draining to play – will want to look elsewhere. The Witcher 2 is bittersweet.

												It's certainly a Badass Action/RPG but considering it's a Sequel, I gotta compare it to the original. 7/10 as a Sequel - 8 or 9/10 if it were an original IP.-Can't stumble around drunk.-No nude cards.-No Sky! Big deal for me. I want stars and ♥♥♥♥. There are some...clouds...I guess...sorta?-Boring companions. At first I was hype to see Dandilion and the Dwarf, but they end up just hanging around not saying ♥♥♥♥. You interacted a lot more with your homies in TW1 and there was some funny stuff, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Voice Acting aside/included.-Crazy bad texture pop-in. Still one of the best looking games around, but the pop-in nearly ruins it.-Dice board isn't as pretty. Just a nitpick, and obviously just my opinion.The main thing that made The Witcher 1 an incredible game was an actual sense of being a Monster Hunter. TW2 does a good job in many ways, but not in the one that I think was most effective.Money. The struggle is real in TW1. You NEED to go hunt down x Monster to make that cash. You need to bar fight and play Dice sometimes. I always really felt like I was truly hunting monsters as a profession, because I -had- to do what I could to make scratch.The other element in TW1 is just being a Witcher in general...potions. I had to max the difficulty of course but, drinking potions and using spells was a huge deal in TW1. Before you enter a cave, you make sure you're set with potions. You take a moment to prepare and drink up before going in. It mattered. At first I thought it was lame. He felt weak, and it seemed pathetic that he needed potions to even fight. But, I adjusted to the fact that he's a "Witcher" and that's how they roll, because normal people can't even drink the potions without damn near dying. I mean, I'm sure he can whoop anybody's ♥♥♥ without the potions, but these are monsters. It made sense when I really thought about it, and added to the strategy.Combat too..not everyone agrees but I thought combat in TW1 was sick as ♥♥♥♥. Loved the stances.Game just had this "vibe" that you can't really put into words as well. Thank you for reading my TL:DR TW1 review.

content:
0, 2014
												My favorite RPG of all time, The Witcher 2 continues the story of Geralt of Rivia. Very adult, shocking at times, gory and with a genuinely interesting storyline as it is based off of the Polish novels by Andrzej Sapkowski. This is not Skyrim, where your decisions are very clear cut to be "good" or "bad". Or Mass Effect, where you are graded on a light or dark scale depending on the moral direction of your decisions. The decisions you are presented with are a series of grays, that you have to evaluate in the moment for not only the manipulation of the kingdom, but also personal gain and survival. Oh, did I mention that some of those decisions you have to make within seconds of being presented them?! No waiting around, researching which story arc you close or open depending on the decision... You have 3 seconds, and you have to deal with the consequences. The world actually reflects a bit of the Game of Thrones attitude... The good guys don't always win.The world itself is full of political intrigue, racism towards elves and dwarves, and tensions between the kings ruling throughout the region. The world, though it can be gorgeous... Reflects this downtrodden atmosphere, and gives a very midieval "grunge" to everything. The graphics themselves are incredible, assuming you have the system for it, and have more "weight" to the textures and character models than I've experienced in some time. The last time I felt this kind of wow factor it was playing the original Gears of War back in 2006, my first real experience with Unreal Engine 3. The combat doesn't babysit you, and if you choose not to use magic or potions you won't last long. There are various oils and gems you can augment weapons with for extra damage, potions you can consume for more resistance to a type of magic or poison, and others yet that help aid your sight in the dark depending on the mission or quest at hand. It includes an alchemy section, wherein you can craft your own potions from herbs and ingrediants you pick up through the game, as well as a very satisfying skill/ability tree that you expand upon throughout the game.All in all, HIGHLY recommended if you can get past the difficulty.

												Easily the best RPG I have played in years.A rich and vivid world that is home to a story that defies typical fantasy cliches. It's a story of complex political intrigue and not the same old good versus evil hogwash.  A rather challenging real time combat system plus the gorgeous graphics make this one of the overall most complete experiences of 2011.Every RPG fan must play this and people that just like a good story as well as graphics freaks will also get their moneys worth out of this for sure.LINUX Port warning (June 2014): Currently the port suffers from abysmal performance issues and quite a number of stability problems due to it being made by a company that used a wrapper instead of porting it native. They are currently working on fixing it but I would not recommend buying it at full price if you are going to play it on Linux. Sale discounts leave the game at around 4€ which might be worth the gamble.

content:
er 29, 2011
												The Witcher 2 is not an RPG for the faint of heart. It will NOT cater to your needs - do not expect it to be easy, or lighthearted, or something to play when you have nothing better to do. It expects you to be Geralt of Rivia, the world's greatest witcher, and you WILL be him or GAME OVER trying. My advice: get a week's supply of popcorn and coke, lock the door to your room to keep out everyone in order to be able to get absolute peace and quiet, and press the PLAY button and disconnect yourself altogether from real life. Allow the living, mysterious world of Andrzej Sapkowski's work to devour you, wasting innumerable hours of your time. The story is incredibly well-written: only in this game is a character who barely survives half the act portrayed as few companies manage to portray characters in a whole frickin' game's plotline. Become the Witcher: it certainly couldn't be simpler.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												Before we proceed, understand that I actually like the gameplay in The Witcher 2. In fact, it's exceptional. Combat is easy to play yet hard to master – an elusive quality in action RPG combat mechanics – with plenty of difficulty and interesting combat scenarios. By the end of the incredibly well put-together tutorial, you'll feel like you honestly participated in medieval siege. A rich and complex crafting system underpins plenty of gameplay interactions and makes many of the incidental bits of junk you collect through the game have real value. And on top of all of this, The Witcher 2 is one of those rare RPGs that flirts with having real consequence to player decisions throughout the dialogue.Thus, I feel I have to give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings a good review score; by every objective standard of game design, development, and production values, it is an excellent game. I cannot recommend it unreservedly, however, as a few things about the game never quite clicked into place for me. I found myself, at the end of it, more stricken by some of the evident gaps in story and gameplay direction than enthusiastic for the inevitable sequel that, presumably, will tie together the numerous loose ends of the storyline.The first Witcher was a game that I had a very hard time playing through. On the one hand, I loved the writing and variety of choice available throughout the dialogue and intrigue portions of the game; on the other hand, most of the momentary gameplay was painfully overcomplicated and obtuse. Any game requiring that I explicitly enter combat mode and then explicitly choose a stance before I can start wailing on dudes loses points in my book. The Witcher 2 eschews many of the more glaring flaws of the original game—a more streamlined UI, a closer camera so you can really see what's going on, and a combat system that emphasizes skill are all welcome additions to the series.There are some distinct flaws in the gameplay, though nothing major. The first and most obvious one is how side quest objectives are communicated. The Witcher 2 has joined the slew of recent games that basically lead you through the objectives to complete side quests (and, actually, main quests) by hand. While I have some objections to that in general, my complaint in this case is more about some of the little gaffes in how that's presented.The next major flaw in the gameplay is that autosaving is used in the game, but not always in intelligent ways. At some boss fights, the game will autosave right before the big introduction cut-scene of the boss. This makes sense if you walk away from the game for a few days after dying to the monster once; but if you're like me, and try again... several times... then needing to blunder through the cut-scene time and again becomes a real nuisance.The third major flaw is that there are unique gameplay modes – such as stealth – which will activate contextually, but you are explicitly told to enter them. Since the game decides when you enter into the mode, why are you telling me to go into the mode? What button is that? Not a big deal by any means, but a little irritation all the same.Graphically and aurally, the Witcher 2 is a very well put-together game. Lush visuals, fantastic texture work, great visual effects, and clear iconography keep the game attractive. The music is, by and large, very fitting, and the sound design tactfully places you in the middle of the events of the game. Lots of nice little touches – folks chopping away at wood in a little village, the crumbling of nearby rocks as you climb down a cliff face, or the occasional snap of twigs as you tromp through the forest – pop out of the speakers regularly. Voice acting is also quite good. I think I take the most issue with the writing and character design. By and large, the Witcher series has a very dim view of most people. Just about everyone is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in The Witcher 2; even Geralt's sorceress girlfriend, the character who the writers tried hardest to make sympathetic, comes off as a catty, jealous ♥♥♥♥♥ at times. It's not that I believe people are always nice and friendly, but when there's not a single decent person to talk to, it gets hard to take any of the characters seriously.The other side of this is that some of the best written, most charismatic and genuinely fun characters to be around don't last terribly long. This is made abundantly clear by the end of the tutorial. Apparently in Witcher world, fun people aren't fit to live.By the end of the game, I found myself left with a distinctly ashen taste in my mouth; the victories are left hollow and incomplete. Partially because the ending doesn't fully resolve the numerous sub-plots of the game, but also because the storyline felt arbitrary and disconnected. The Witcher's style – weirdly dark and artificially edgy, especially for a fantasy title – creates disjointed storylines that, even when the promised ending occurs, are a letdown.I also might mention that The Witcher 2 represents a... particular view of women. If you are comfortable seeing women portrayed as little more than ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥, then this is the game for you! If, on the other hand, you find the lack of strong female characters in games to be irritating, then this really isn't for you. Triss and Ves, two of the notable female characters of the game, don't count, by the way; both spend most of their screen-time in form-fitting outfits, prancing their overly shapely asses about the focus point of the camera and generally requiring Geralt's manly help to accomplish much of anything.Despite all the little flaws and caveats, The Witcher 2 is, ultimately, a fantastic game; any fan of darker, more consequentialist fiction will find themselves right at home. Nevertheless, those of you looking for something more upbeat, more uplifting – and frankly, less draining to play – will want to look elsewhere. The Witcher 2 is bittersweet.

content:
y 31, 2015
												It's certainly a Badass Action/RPG but considering it's a Sequel, I gotta compare it to the original. 7/10 as a Sequel - 8 or 9/10 if it were an original IP.-Can't stumble around drunk.-No nude cards.-No Sky! Big deal for me. I want stars and ♥♥♥♥. There are some...clouds...I guess...sorta?-Boring companions. At first I was hype to see Dandilion and the Dwarf, but they end up just hanging around not saying ♥♥♥♥. You interacted a lot more with your homies in TW1 and there was some funny stuff, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Voice Acting aside/included.-Crazy bad texture pop-in. Still one of the best looking games around, but the pop-in nearly ruins it.-Dice board isn't as pretty. Just a nitpick, and obviously just my opinion.The main thing that made The Witcher 1 an incredible game was an actual sense of being a Monster Hunter. TW2 does a good job in many ways, but not in the one that I think was most effective.Money. The struggle is real in TW1. You NEED to go hunt down x Monster to make that cash. You need to bar fight and play Dice sometimes. I always really felt like I was truly hunting monsters as a profession, because I -had- to do what I could to make scratch.The other element in TW1 is just being a Witcher in general...potions. I had to max the difficulty of course but, drinking potions and using spells was a huge deal in TW1. Before you enter a cave, you make sure you're set with potions. You take a moment to prepare and drink up before going in. It mattered. At first I thought it was lame. He felt weak, and it seemed pathetic that he needed potions to even fight. But, I adjusted to the fact that he's a "Witcher" and that's how they roll, because normal people can't even drink the potions without damn near dying. I mean, I'm sure he can whoop anybody's ♥♥♥ without the potions, but these are monsters. It made sense when I really thought about it, and added to the strategy.Combat too..not everyone agrees but I thought combat in TW1 was sick as ♥♥♥♥. Loved the stances.Game just had this "vibe" that you can't really put into words as well. Thank you for reading my TL:DR TW1 review.

content:
, 2015
												I was a big fan of the first one, despite it seeming a little old school. It had a rich story, and the choice and consequence system gave it a depth and replay value not unlike Mass Effect. This one, the combat got upgraded to be more action paced, which was VERY nice. Everything awesome about the first one has been continued or improved with the small exception of potions/alchemy. There are some features they took out from the Witcher 1 to Witcher 2, but you learn to get past it. This game feels a little shorter, but a little better paced, especially if trying to be a completionist. I have unlocked every achievement on this game and there is no sweeter feeling than earning Madman! The way the story unfolds gives this game just as much if not more replay value than its predecessor and should prompt anyone to be excited for the upcoming third installment! This is a great game in a great series!

On par with DA, ME, TESV.Story is overwhelmingly captivating (I wonder if witcher saga author himself had his hand in it).The game looks incredible (especially for 3 year-old title).And here's a little checklist to grab:Elves, dwarves, magic users, dungeons and dragons. Check.Realistic and ever-changing world, resembling middle-ages europe. Check.Political intrigues, plots and coups. Check.Tough choices, moral crossroads. Check.Visceral, really fun combat (unlike 1st game). Check.Bar brawls, brothels, arm wrestling, dice poker. Check.Racist insurgents, spy wenches, infamous special forces unit. Check.Drunkard troll. Check.So? Do I have to say more? Grab the ploughin' game and go play it!

content:
r 10, 2016
												TLDR:-This game is phenominal, buy it.Long Version:My first experience with The Witcher was the third game. I decided to play through the first two for background then the third one again. I expected the first two games to be a drag, especially after being spoiled by the graphics and gameplay of The Witcher 3. I was pleasantly surpised, to the point that I decided to restart the first game after skipping most of the side quests in the first two chapters. I also decided to read the novels and short stories to gain a greater understanding of the characters and story in the games. I am extremely glad I did. Not only do they obviously give you a much greater understanding of the aforementioned elements, but they are also phenomenal stories by themselves. This game has stood the test of time surprisingly well, and is definitely worth your money, even at full price, though, if you are willing to wait, you could get it much cheaper on sale, as I did.

content:
, 2014
												PC conf : Core i7 / 8 GO Ram / GTX 560. Running smoothly at full settings EXCEPT UBER SAMPLING.I 100%d this game (yes I did the insane mode thingy I have no life) so you may guess I quite liked it.The Witcher 2 is sequel to The Witcher (which is actually a really boring game in which developpers took too many risks that didn't really pay off ; and I wouldn't recommend you to buy it). You are Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher (some kind of Mutant with magical powers and high sword mastery) and you have friends (!!) that follow you in your quest, aka regain your memory.What is a Witcher : 


YouTube™ Video: What is a Witcher 

			Views: 0		

			The video presents the history of the legendary class of monster slayers known as the witchers from the upcoming action RPG, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition.		

At the end of The Witcher, Geralt saves King Foltest from another witcher's assassination attemp and afterwards Foltest asks him to join and protect him. At the beginning of The Witcher 2, Foltest does die and Geralt is somehow accused by the entire realm. His quest will then be to find the real assassin and to burnish his acts. So despite his notorious "neutrality" the famed witcher Geralt will be forced to make alliances and choices that will define his story and most importantly the story of the world around him.And this is what I enjoyed the most in The Witcher 2 : its non-linearity that makes it highly replayable. I'm not spoiling anything but in chapter 1 you are given the opportunity to make a choice that will COMPLETELY CHANGE THE GAME (I'm talking WHOLE DIFFERENTS AREAS AND QUESTS !) ; so when you buy this game it's like you're buying not just one but 2 or 3 games, son ! And the quests are really attracting in the sense that you will really want to do that sidequest because it's fun and well designed... and you need money to stop dying in two hits with your naked butt.Let's talk about the character and the lore : The Witcher's universe is a very dense and complex universe, hence you should feel free to have the wiki open next to you when you play the game (of course making sure you don't spoil yourself too much) to make sure that you can enjoy every bit of this complex universe and not just give up because "♥♥♥♥ it, the story is too complicated and what the ♥♥♥♥ is that amnesia people are all talking about".Characters in the Witcher are designed so that they are all different, all have political implications and are memorable thanks to their design, agressivity, sexual orientation/relationships with the hero since The Witcher 2 is a mature game (sex boys !) ; or whatever... The graphics and level of details given throughout the entire game also helps a lot with this (yeah the game is one of the best-looking thing ever designed and I hope you upgrade your PC or it could have a bad time).The universe in which you play in is pretty big although it is far from being any kind of open world. The developpers focused on bringing some kind of "medieval reality" back to life. Reality is something important in The Witcher and you will have to deal with both small fighting areas and huge lands.Fighting and the combat system may give you a hard time at first (do not hesitate to change the difficulty level to easy if you're more of a casual player and difficulty prevents you from enjoying the game), but I hope that like me you will feel like it's one of the best and realistic combat systems ever designed : Geralt isn't immortal, he dies fast, however he can roll like a car tyre. If you are really having a hard time in the early stages then don't give up and let me tell you that the game becomes easier as Geralt levels up (which goes really fast with the main quest, and there is a max level of 35).Hardcore gamers rejoice, Dark Mode is here for you. Get ready to cry if you do it on your first playthrough.The Witcher 2 is unique and I deeply thing any kind of player can enjoy it in some way, probably the best RPG of its generation, I found the story much more compelling than Skyrim and have to go with the10/10, must play and precommand The Witcher 3 !

content:
, 2014
												A lot can be said about this game. It has its great moments, but also some very lame sides. First, the positive things about this game: It is a nicely done rpg with lots of costumization possibilities. You can not travel between cities and have to follow the plot of the game, but once you're in a city, you are free to explore it however you want to. There are lots of side quests and the main plot itself is very interesting. The side quests are also meaningful and mostly fund, not of the "fetch me this flowe" kind. The game is clearly made for adults, since there's a lot of brutality and nudity in it. This is nice to see in an era where almost every game is being made for all audiences. The crafting system is also one of the strong features of Witcher 2. You can craft weapons, armor, potions, traps etc.On the other hand, there are some things which ruin the game. The checkpoint (aka autosave) system is a failure. You watch a cutscene, you listen to a conversation and then get to the fight scene. If you die, you don't get to fight again immediately; no you have to watch the cutscene again (which you can skip btw) and listen to the conversation (which you can click through). It is very annoying to constantly have to click your way to the fight after every death and it only adds to your frustration. There are also instances in the game where you don't control your main character, but you are rather given the control of a character in the story to fight. The game is almost telling you "Hey remember all those skills you gained through collecting experience and all? Yeah, they're gone. Have fun!". This is very very frustrating. In the end, you should make up your mind: can you endure the frustration of this game to enjoy its exciting plot and positive features?tl;dr Witcher 2 is a beautiful game with some very annoying bull**** in it.

content:
22, 2014
												This game is superb in almost every aspect. It has a very well connected story with mature content and its "replayability" is  enough to spend more than 40-50 hours playing it. The game is closer to a linear than a non-linear game, but in a certain way that's what makes the story special, because you can realize how the decisions you make change the story/world through each chapter (still, the player has a wide freedom in each chapter, excluding the prologue/epilogue). The script is written in a way that sometimes decisions are extremely hard to make, something that I liked a lot. Sidequest in this game are well made and worth your time since they are mainly separate stories which will engulf you even more in the game, also, they sometimes have *minor* impact in the main plot.The combat and skill tree is ok, better than in TW1 IMO, in the end it depends on your tastes.Graphics are really well made since this game uses dx9. Personally, I didn't like the way the shadows were made and I miss some tessellation especially on the floor, but I guess that it is the cost in exchange for better perfomance.The soundtrack is awesome and every track fits every part of the game. A must have for RPG lovers. 8.8/10

												The Witcher 2 grabs ones attention with it's stunning graphics and well designed environments but it's the compelling story lines which keeps the player coming back for more. What makes The Witcher 2 unique from other RPGs is the ability for the player's actions to have a real effect on the progression of the story lines and similarly the world around them. Even the side quests are interesting elements of this game and can also make a difference on how things pan out. Although there are some linear sections sprinkled throughout the game, the developers have done a good job ensuring these don't feel too constraining to the player. For gamers who enjoy well written and in depth story lines, The Witcher 2 is definitely worth a play through; however for those who aren't interested in complex story lines and prefer more focus on hacking and slashing this might not be the game for you.
