content:
24, 2012
												The Witcher 2 is an exemplarary sequel that manages to build upon the strengths of the Witcher 1, namely it's combat mechanics and plot twists, while addressing and improving on it's predecessor's flaws . An outstanding Role Playing Game, no two replays of this game will ever be the same. In the Witcher 2, you are thrust into the character of Geralt of Rivia, famed monster slayer and unintended savior of a king, where you must make the decisions that alter the fates of not only the protagonist but the world and its many characters about him. Its a compelling narrative about maintaining neutrality in a world that is morally ambiguous and deceptive. You will feel the sting of unintended consequences, and with a variety of supporting characters, all whose lives and motivations you will come to understand, decisions in this game are not made lightly . Aside from its storyline, the actual mechanics of the gameplay are superbly executed. Combat is visceral and tactical. Magic, Alchemy, and swordplay are your means of defeating your enemies, and the Witcher 2 introduces a menagerie containing all sorts of monsters, both fantastically gargantuan & sometimes human, whose strengths/weaknesses must be taken into account, especially on the hardest of difficulties. In the end, the Witcher 2 is a satisfying video game with a storyline that leaves it's impression upon you because of it's relation to your impact as Geralt. I'm optimistic about this franchise and look forward to future sequels.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												The Witcher 2 was a wonderful game in all aspects and a major improvement over the first game in the series. Geralt isn't only dealing with Temeria anymore. The fate of all the Northern Kingdoms is at stake. The story and narration lives up to the hype of the first, and in fact, has Geralt making many more decisions with varying consequences. Characters are much more fleshed out. Be prepared to face situations where you're wedged between two characters that you like, only being able to help one of them. Many times, decisions simply don't have a right answer, and other times it can be good vs bad mystery that you have to decipher by paying attention to clues given to you. You get to shape Geralt to become the character you want. My main complaint, is that the game eventually forces you to a fork in the road. This decision essentially takes over a full chapter in the story, and I although you get to visit places from both paths in one playthrough, you can end up missing a lot of important story elements if you aren't careful. I ended up glossing over the sidequest for an important character in the Witcher 3 because I was so invested in finishing the main quest. It's also totally neat to see decisions carry over from the previous game, and don't forget, the decisions you make also carry over to the Witcher 3!Combat has been completely overhauled. Say goodbye to the timed clicks, because the new combat system is entirely momentum based. The new perk tree allows Geralt to fight as a swordsman, a mage, a hunter, or any combination. Sword swings are dictated with the left and right mouse buttons, alllowing Geralt to alternate between fast or strong slashes. Enemies will flinch when attacked, giving your offenses a sense of weight. Spells and sidearms can be conveniently selected and used via a quickbar, and Geralt can roll around dodging attacks like a madman. There's still much room for improvement, however. Fighting still feels a bit clunky at times, and ragdolls (or the lack of) can make killing enemies really awkward because they just topple over. Attacks from bosses can also have extended hitboxes, as I have died many times over after getting clipped by an attack that was seemingly out of my range. Rolling may become your primary means of mobility, and it can be troublesome to use. Enemies will tend to swarm you, and blocking/reposting leaves you vulnerable from other angles while rolling may tumble you into other enemies. It's all about tactically positioning yourself, which can be seen as a welcome challenge, or an eventual annoyance. I will definitely say that there is a high learning curve to this new combat style. Unlike the first Witcher, which has Geralt acquire each of his Witcher signs throughout the game, the Witcher 2 throws all of the signs at you at once, along with a load of projectiles and potions which aren't explained very well at all. I totally failed the tutorial, which suggested for me to play on easy. I was still able to complete the game on hard, but it was far from easy. Aside from the main gameplay, you can also participate in dice poker, arm wrestling, and brawls (QTE simulator). They weren't that fun, but hey, they're not nothing.Graphically, the game is beautifully designed. The forest outside Flotsam was densely packed with greenery and looked totally sinister at night time. It was dissapointing that there were no major cities to explore, but each settlement Geralt visits has a unique rugged atmosphere. I do think that the world is a bit oversaturated, though. Colors tend to be very sharp. Characters also have great face textures, and unique characters have great memorable designs. Unfortunately, a lot of models are reused throughout the game for minor characters. The music, although my least favorite of the three Witcher games, still isn't bad at all. There was a wide array of scores that fit both emotional and intense scenes from the game. To me, the soundtrack just sounded more like stereotypical fantasy music as opposed to The Witcher or The WItcher 3 (hands down my favorite!). Still, try listening to the song Sorceresses. It's quite enchanting.In the end despite some flaws, The Witcher 2 was a true fantasy RPG mixed with exceedingly challenging yet rewarding combat. I highly recommend playing the original Witcher to get a better sense of the massive story/world and a basic handling for Geralts abilities. It is defintely an exciting experience to learn about the world of the WItcher. Pros:-Great interactive story filled with morality-based decisions-Challenging but rewarding combat-Interesting and well designed recurring characters-Beautiful level design-Solid soundtrackCons: -Combat can seem a bit unrefined-Newbies to the Witcher may have a hard time finding their footing-Fork in the road can cause you to miss some story elementsTL;DR: Play as Geralt of Rivia, the White Wolf, as you choose the lesser evil, mess around with spells, roll all over the place during fights, and die a lot.

												I really wish they would quit advertising this game for linux on the front page of steam.. Keep selling it for linux if they must, but its advertisement as being available for steamos/linux has been on the front page for far too long. This is not what we want linux noobs to try and play and think this is what linux gaming is about.. they have heard enough crap about gaming on linux and this only adds fuel to the negative press linux gets as a gaming platform. Yes it starts up.. and yes you can technically "play" it. Though I cannot suggest anybody play this title in linux. I had picked it up on sale and never really played it until the linux version came out and I finally got excited for it only to be really let down. It is NOT a native linux title by any stretch of the imagination as it uses a "wine type" wrapper to make it run on linux. So just deal with it and play this game on windows if you are going to play it. I will not "not" recomend this game as it's gorgeous if you have the hardware for it and from what I have played is a great game. I am just adding to the growing list of warnings about this title for linux so the linux noobs don't get the wrong idea.EDIT* Forgot I wrote this, I should note that they made great strides in getting the performance of the EON wrapper to a much more acceptable level and I can actually recommend it to be played in Linux now. Don't expect it to run as well as in windows but it is certainly acceptable IMO.

content:
19, 2015
The ConsipracyCD Project RED have sold their souls in exchange for creating perfect digital art.The Original ClassicI remember back then, when the first Witcher came out it was something refreshing, captivating, even good, but still it wasn’t spectacular, despite some people calling it a new best RPG. Among its great strengths in story, quests, art and music it definitely had glaring issues: most notably, some annoying (to the point of being silly) combat moves and the fact that a good two thirds of it is spent in some sort of swamps, sewers and similar-looking dungeons.There was no hint of something huge coming ahead.Enter the Mighty SequelBut suddenly and unexpectedly, The Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings is upon us. And here I am, trying to review it with my jaw dropped and dangling somewhere around my knees.You are Geralt, a witcher — a professional monster slayer caught in a midst of political conflict, intrigue and soon after that, on a long quest to clear your good name and discover more pieces in attempt to solve a puzzle of Wild Hunt and your dark past.Now this is something like ubelievable upgrade over previous installement, unmatched by anything in recent history. Everything you can possibly think of have been drastically improved, expanded and taken to breathtaking levels of visuals, music and sound. All environments are unique and are extremely rich in details: there’s no copy-paste ever.The characters, even NPCs, are alive, deep and interesting. There’s no other RPG where you would stop just to listen to NPC talk and smile at some story they tell each other. Every place, every spot, be it in town or outside, has an event connected to it and some amazing quest you can take on: escape from prison (be a master of stealth, or you can make it a little rough), participate in an assault on rebellious town alongisde king and teach his stupid son some good lesson, prevent military abuse of innocent civillians by beating an officer in a one-on-one swordfight, and get away with it because your king favors you so much; visit abandoned and haunted asylum to calm down the spirits of its victims and learn about its grim past, uncover treason and crime, take a taste of dirty medieval town life by participating in brawls, dice poker and arm wrestling games — and earn some additional coin with that!But There’s Much More!Meet mages, trolls (friendly and not so much), fight a giant Cthulhu with a sorceress by your side, join elves in their guerilla struggle against humans, assist dwarves and visit their mysterious town hidden somewhere deep in the mountains or, if you rather prefer that, stay in a dirty human military camp and become a new star of its colloseum-like fighting arena. The choice is always yours: so be prepared to take it and face the consequences (or enjoy them :-).CombatAnd did I even mention how great fights can be? Devise your tactics, approach and hunt monsters: all different, inhabiting their own areas and requiring unique means to successfully kill; pursue finest gear upgrades to assist yourself in your dirty job. Harvest for ingredients during your trips outside to brew and drink awesome poisions (of a witcher sort) and acquire inhuman powers for a short amount time. Buy materials, schematics and construct deadly traps, bombs and daggers to leave your enemies no chance. Approach several knights that dared to threaten you and perform a powerful finisher move, killing them all at once. Redirect arrows back at your enemies, use powerful witcher magic tricks to trap or stun your foes: block, riposte, perform a quick roll away, then jump and cut your unfortunate foe through while he recovers from a good blast of your yrden (not a typo). You have to fight dirty: you have to fight like a witcher.And all that above is just barely one third of what is in store for you.ConclusionI have no idea how CDPR were able to pull that all off.(Disregard my hours, I own it from elsewhere.)* * *[A blast of fire from dragon’s breath]— Witcher, how do you fight something like THIS?!— You don’t, you run.— Some professional you are!Outstanding.

content:
9, 2015
												The Witcher 2 continues the epic story of professional monster slayer for hire; Geralt of Rivia. If you have played the first game you will probably already have an idea of what you can expect. The Witcher 2 begins a few months after the events of the first game. If you haven't played the first you may be a bit at a loss with regards to some elements in the story.Without spoiling the story you proceed through the game searching for the 'kingslayer' and the choices you make will ultimately decide the ending of the story you get. (This ending can then be transferred to Witcher 3.) You follow one of two main story paths. You either can side with blue stripes commander Vernon Roche or with Scoitatel renegade and guerilla fighter Lor'veth. The combat in Witcher 2 has been refined considerably from the first game. whereas the first game relied on a timing mechanic; The Witcher 2 adds in things like parry's to the mix. I strongly recommend playing the first game prior as it will give greater context to the events that occur in this follow up. I also strongly recommend playing this game prior to Witcher 3 for the same reason. However the Witcher 3 does a decent job of providing additional information about the world and characters. You can find these in in-game character profiles as well as books you can find during your playthrough.As you can see it took me about 40 or so hours to play through the game. But this is a game where your investment will pay off with a satisfying conclusion that you can then build on in the Witcher 3. If you are looking for a deep story driven RPG where there is no 'right' choice; and for those choices to matter? Witcher 2 is a fantastic choice.

ry 12, 2016
												Alright, I'm here! I'm very late to the party, but finally I'm here. It only took close to five years. What took me so long, you ask? Well, part of the answer is that I'm not that into RPGs, but I've heard so much good about The Witcher 3 so I had to play the second to be able to import the save file to the third game. "But why didn't you play the first game?", good question. I did play the first game for some hours, but as many others I stopped due to it's fighting mechanics being really bad. Storywise, it was just fine.So, what did I think about this game? It's a great looker, even though it has been five years since its first release (Enhanced Edition was released a year later). The voice acting is as solid as expected - especially Geralt's voice. The background music is really fitting and ups the mood for the player, really bombastic and energetic music when there's a huge battle against a dragon or something like that. The story was great and can't wait to see how they continue it in the third game.But most of all - if you're a fan of RPGs and you haven't play this one yet, I do recommend you do that. When there's a sale, you can get this game for less than €5, that's NOTHING.

content:
ry 8, 2016
												What can I say about this game, it's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. A while back I played through the first Witcher game. While the graphics were alright and the combat system was at times dreadful, I still enjoyed that game very much. Its setting and story made up for whatever shortcomings it had. After quite some time, I decided to jump onto The Witcher 2, now that The Witcher 3 is cheap enough for me to eventually buy. Enough of my rambling, onto the review itself.The Witcher 2 feels like a much better version of The Witcher 1. The graphics are improved, the combat system is simple, but intricate at times, and the story once again delivers. While playing this game, I read that the chapter lengths and overall length of the game was a bit disappointing. On average, it took many gamers around 30 hours to beat the game. I'm sure if you are a sidequest freak, it would take much longer. The first Witcher game took me around 60 hours to beat and that felt good. Not too long, but not too short. Initially, I was frustrated at the game's length, but the more I played, the more I felt that the game was concise and it managed to perform well within its time constraints. Any longer than that and the game's quality would've suffered. Towards the end, I kept thinking that if The Witcher 2 is this awesome, The Witcher 3 must be one of the best games of all time. I know I'm late when it comes to The Witcher franchise, but these are games that I will most likely be playing on a regular basis for years to come. I give this game a 4/5 and I definitely recommend it.

content:
2015
												*Disclaimer A: This is an ongoing review, I'll update it once I progress further into the game**Disclaimer B: This review was originally a negative one, it now has been edited*Thank you, killJoy12345! My initial review was very negative. It was based on me trying the game with a controller. Here is recommendation no.1: Do not try to play this with a controller. Who knows, I am sure some will succeed playing the game with one... I didn't. At all. The tutorial alone, attempted with an Xbox-controller, frustrated me so much that I had to quit right in the middle of the arena. It just felt so incredibly imprecise, confusing, clunky and weird. I compared it to being drunk out of your mind while trying to control an overloaded 40 ton-truck with a wobbly old joystick from the early 80s or something. I quit and uninstalled, not bothering to try again as I had bought this for like 3 bucks during a sale. I have changed my mind very much, and am falling more in love with the game the longer I play it, and I think I start to understand just why the game is so revered. I am now playing this with a mouse and a keyboard. The mouse to look around and using my attacks, the keyboard for moving. I use a Razer Naga, and with the number keys on its side, it's quite easy to control using the standard/default key settingsWith these numbers (with the Naga or keyboard), WASD, Q and R plus the Alt key to target-lock, the controls get much better. I'd also recommend to adjust the mouse settings, and lower the sensitivity. With the naga, it's set to the lowest possible value. This works well for looking around without being too slow, plus it is precise enough to handle the arm-wrestling minigame (which you need for a quest, where you do that instead of paying with money). Said arm-wrestling takes a tiny bit of practice, but I was then able to beat most opponents. Now for the game itself. Graphics/Setting/storyI said that the graphics are merely ok. I kinda stick to that, even considering the game isn't brand-new. They're quite pretty, but they're not exactly total state of the art even for the time it came out IMO. They ARE quite atmospheric though, and help to suck you into the game. And gee, there is a lot to be sucked into, as the game REALLY is quite addictive and enticing IMO. The story is quite interesting... a bit of cliché sometimes, but mainly a well-written and multi-layered story. Depending on how you want to play Geralt, you can be either a nice goodie-two-shoes, sticking to a moral high-road, or you can be a rather intimidating, threatening and sinister figure, doing whatever it takes to achieve his goal. The dialogues are nice, sometimes you have to pick your answers quickly. I am not that far into the game yet... I mentioned this will be an ongoing review, I will add updates once I progress more. So far, I am VERY into it, want to see how the story plays out, want to learn more about the world it is set in. Handling/Controls/FightingI mentioned above that the combination of KB plus Naga works quite well. I still need to practice a bit, as some of the controls are a bit...wobbly. It sometimes takes a tiny bit longer to target a lootbag, ladder, climbing/point. Fighting feels pretty dynamic, and you can succeed even if you don't target-lock enemies. So far, it was pretty much up to me how I wanted to fight mobs... using mostly swords, signs or quickslots (traps/bombs/daggers). I am sure that later on, you need to decide on some of these for specific mobs, acting with a bit more tactic, while right now, I am slashing my way through the mobs rather easily while throwing in an occasional Aard or Ignis for tougher mobs or those that shield themselves. Regarding controls and handling, this game gets a 7 or 8 out of 10 so far. I wish it'd feel a bit more precise especially out of combat, when you pick up stuff or loot. Not as good as some AC or Arkham-titles in my opinion.Update: Just did the first boss fight, and it was tough. I did have to do some research on YT. An NPC gives you SOME hints during the fight, but Im not sure how much they'd help to figure out the correct tactic without help. However, I eventually beat it, and it was quite satisfying. Soundtrack/Voice actingVery very nicely done. The music isn't annoying you, it rather adds to the atmosphere, and even with quite a few repetitions, it doesnt get boring. Pros:- Graphics are decent to very nice. Not mind-blowing, but pretty dang good.- Music and voice-acting are very well done and work nicely for the vibe.- FIghting feels dynamic... even if sometimes it's buggy (fighting my way out of a prison often had me light or extinguish torches on the wall while trying to actually slash away at a guard. Didn't die, but the combination of "use torch with left-click, slash at opponent with... left click" wasnt helpful.I hear Witcher III will be even better when it comes to controls.- Interesting and deep story, very nice to follow and read, even though there are a LOT of plotlines and chars, so maybe some extra research at a wiki would be helpful to understand it better. Cons- Controls often are a bit too wobbly, not quite precise enough. If they weren't, the game would be close to absolutely perfect. This doesn't apply much to the fight, but more to everything in between.- 2 crashes so far, hope this doesn't happen more often. The game does autosave, but I recommend to manually save from time to time. 2nd crash was on exiting an instance, and not even CTL AlT DEL would help to close the crashed game (funny: the "loading icon" was still moving, but the game had crashed)- One big immersion-killer: You can't jump. Yes, you can jumproll in certain directions while fighting to dodge attacks (direction key plus space, took me a bit of practice). So this powerful demon hunter walks through the area, and there is a 10 inch rise in the landscape... you can't raise a foot or jump up, you have to walk all around it. This kinda kills the immersion and feels weird. I guess they wanted to do this to guide you with paths in between rises, but that adds a "on rails" feeling while also feeling very unnatural. - Some of the QTEs are very fast and you might fail a few times, especially since the first ones happen quite surprisingly. DOn't worry, they won't kill you quickly, you just need to adjust quickly in order to succeed. YMMV:- Your questlog fills up rather quickly. A lot of the quests have a tracker to help you find the right spot and person, but some require you to think or search a bit. Also, read the questlog (which is well-written!). If you are used to WOW-type questing, with handholding to the extreme, TLDR-summaries at the bottom and trackers for every single quest, you might have to readjust. - Some might dislike the minigames like the wrestling. It does take practice for sure.- The menus can be quite overwhelming at first. Alchemy, talent trees, meditation etc... take your time.And that leads me to one big piece of advice: I think (at least so far) this game is MUCH more enjoyable if you take your time and savor each step. Watch the cutscenes. Read the questlogs and information provided. Enjoy the quests and solving them instead of trying to rush through them as much as possible. Try some different approaches to fights, don't ignore the quickslot items or potions or signs. If you prefer swordplay, then go ahead, but I recommend to try different styles, or mix them up a bit. I haven't fought a boss-yet... so far, the game hints that it will be a bit of work to kill the first one, and requires tactics. I hope it does, and I hope I will figure it out.So, for now: A solid 9/10, very fascinating and immersive, with a cool story, cool main-character, a very nice and sinister vibe to it (the 18-rating is pretty appropriate as far as I can tell), and it's obvious that a LOT of work went into this. WILL UPDATE!

content:
er 29, 2015
												Where The Witcher was a great game itself, this one tops it easily.The characters are fewer, less confusing and all still have their own background which you get to know. Most of the old characters from witcher 1 are back in the game, right by your side. The fact that the main part of the story is entirely different, depending on you descisions, is just one of the things that make this game replayable. It even goes so far that you don't even see the entire area the game would take place in if your choices would be different. And that is an area large enough to cover about 10 - 15 hours of gameplay!The combat system is particularly harder than in Witcher 1, quite challengíng, while some of the bosses seem to be nearly impossible, even on normal. Some minor things got me still... Why am I not able to walk through doors on myself? There is always a half-second animation doing that for me... come on I can fight around 10 enemies at once... I can manage an unarmed door...Sometimes it is not so easy to tell what Geralt is about so say. The answer is always just short for what he will say, but I went all "Women can't neither fight, nor rule a country!" when I just tried to asked "Could you explain that further?"And so on... Recommended to play before the witcher 3 to get the background story and insert a safegame.Total play time around 30 hours, 20 hours less than witcher I due to large improvements of the GUI and the overall handling.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 8, 2016
												Rating: 8/10Budget: Worth it. Replayability: I recommend spoiling the game for yourself, and reading ahead with a walkthrough to make the right choices. The game is simply too heavy for a casual gamer like myself to go through more than once. But what a journey! Lenght: I'm ashamed to admit how long it took me to beat this game...The Witcher II allows you to import your save from Witcher I, which is exactly as great as it sounds. Remember Mass Effect 2? Trying to start the game without importing a save from ME 1 always kinda sucked, because so many quests would be different - or gone. The problems already start here. The best gear in Witcher 1 is basically junk equipment in Witcher 2. This is a bit ridiculous. Your powers and your level from witcher 1 seems to have no impact on how great you start out in Witcher 2. Balancer, you say? I say no. Frankly, a few powers and some good gear doesn't make enough of a difference in the Witcher 2 for it to have mattered. What matters is practice, tactics and difficulty level. I don't really care much for the gameplay of the Witcher 1 or 2. They're not even that similar. It's sort of a strange "dodge&strike" combat system, reminisce of console hack&slash games. Probably why it's popular with a larger crowd. I don't care for this. I'm more into fps/third person direct control like Skyrim, Jedi Knight 2 or the up-coming Kingdom Come: Deliverance. The style of gameplay in the Witcher is very popular though - just not with me. The story is very rich, but I sometimes feel like the screenplay could use a bit more depht. Don't get me wrong, the story is masterfully written, the characters are intense and interesting and the graphics are very good for a game that is now a aged title, but the actual screen play, the over-used voice actors and character models... I have unpleasant flashbacks to TES IV Oblivion. Sometimes it also seems like the lines chosen by the people in the game are a bit... Artificial. I'm obviously over-criticising the game at this point - It really is a great roleplaying game. But be warned, the only character custimization you can do is a hair-style and clothes beyond skills. The reason I'm giving it 8/10 isn't because of my personal dislike of the combat system - I realize that the combat system is very good, and exactly what the company aimed for. No, my issue is with the items that scale ridiculously in the game, in effeciency, and with the broken econimics of the game. I HONESTLY recommend cheating in this game. You will have a much more enjoyable experience. You're playing as a supernatural monster slayer who is a mutant with magic powers who works for several kings and the king's special forces. Your lover is a sorcerer who wields powerful magic, and you know pretty much everyone who is worth knowing, plus you already ♥♥♥♥ing saved the world once in the Witcher 1. Why are you not rich? Why do you not have good stuff? Why are you not powerful when the game starts? These questions boggle me, and frankly I found the game much more enjoyable with a few cheats. I even bothered to raise the difficulty a bit again, before I decided "Easiest" was the way to go when I found no enjoyment in the combat system at all. Play the Witcher 1 first though!

content:
13, 2015
												They took everything great in the Witcher 1 (the story, the dialogues, the immersion...) and made it better by upgrading the graphics, the gameplay and the character design. I really recommend this game, and if you plan on playing the 3rd, don't hesitate to play this one too (or even the first one if you are not afraid of the difference in gameplay).I have only sided with the Scoia'tael yet (same as in the Witcher 1 as it seemed to be the only reasonable choice to me) but I already know that I'll replay it siding with the other faction as both groups are ambiguous.I would just recommend to take a few mods to make it more enjoyable (nexus account is free) :http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/276/? : automatically hides the UI out of combat.http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/697/? : Geralt is supposed to use pirouettes, not rolling on the ground, this mod just changes the animation for dodges to make it more book friendly.http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/115/? : this one is maybe the most important as the most annoying thing in this game is that all items are way too heavy (including all ingredients for potions/bombs)A few advices for beginners : I see people complaining about the tutorial at the beginning... it's actually because there isn't really one ; I would then recommend anyone to just check the different controls online, recommend you to use potions (always use the regenerative one), oils on your blade (they increase dramatically the damages you deal to enemies) and runes on your weapons and armors. The steel sword is for the humans and the silver one is for all kind of monsters, and if you have a doubt wether it's a monster or a human, use the silver one.

content:
2015
												The Witcher 2 isn't a perfect game. The inventory system is pretty terrible compared to Witcher 1's, blade oils and potions have been downgraded significantly  (and  the timers for them, now reduced to a few minutes at most, don't seem to pause during dialogue, meaning if you don't skip through dialogue after reading the subtitles you might spent several potions and oils preparing for a fight only get into a pre-fight dialogue and have them all unwittingly wasted away), and the magical signs in turn have been buffed to the point of almost being broken, with Yrden in particular rendering most bosses trivial. The dice poker is now a single-round exercise in trying to move your mouse as microscopically as you can in order to not cause every dice to go canonballing off of the board, and the fistfighting diversion is now just a bunch of QTEs.But when you look past all that, The Witcher 2 is by far one of the better RPGs of its generation. The dialogue and general writing are great, and the politics and general lore are more fleshed out and interesting than in the first game. The quest design in general has been greatly improved, and even though there are less monster hunting quests than in the first game they're generally deeper, involving you researching the monsters and doing specific goals to fully eradicate the threat instead of just lobbing off a few heads and turning them in. The game is overall shorter than the first game, but only because it branches off after the first chapter and essentially becomes two different stories which then further branch out, leading to plenty of replayability. You'll have forgotten all of the flaws I listed up above within the first chapter of the game, and it's overall definitely worth a purchase if you're into RPGs.

So I finished it in wine before playing witcher 2.

content:
er 19, 2014
												Performance:Really impressed with how well-made the new engine is. Loads faster(which is kind of surprising because the first game's load times weren't even long), stutters less, and, of course, looks prettier. And I mean much prettier. You don't expect games that look this much better than their prequels to actually perform better than them.The only things about it that I don't like are the differed rendering(alternate form of rendering that only supports [and works] [with] a form of anti-aliasing that has been specifically coded into the game, cancelling out any kind of AA forced on from your graphics control panel. Use SweetFX for AA.), sharpness filter(you'll wanna turn it off in your user config, but make sure to force Anisotrophic Filtering on), and the bloom. The bloom.. I usually am ok with bloom in my games, but I had to turn this game's off. There is just too much of it. For my eyes, anyway.Graphics settings:Many graphics settings available for tweaking. There's a lot you can make changes to that will help the game run better on your rig, if it needs itControls:Controls are greatly improved. Dodging actually works consistently, unlike in the last game. Same with parrying. Same with attacking. I remember instances in the first Witcher where the system sometimes wouldn't let me attack opponents if they were close to me or surrounded me or just didn't let me attack them(while not stunned, etc). When attacking, you use either the left or right mouse button. Either are for heavy or light attacks. Is not like the first Witcher where you select an attack style and click on a foe. The buttons are the styles, so they have to be used/pressed after each attack. Can be combined.They took out the feature that let's you press/hold a button/key to highlight/display whatever in view can be interacted with, as well as the the feature that's you select what you want to interact with the cursor, while you hold/press a button. It's not that big of a deal not having it, but you now have to just run up to something you see, and click on it to do whatever with it.Gameplay:Am a few hours into the game, but can say it's very much like the first. Only, better.Combat is same, but more engaging. Also kinda harder(but I was playing on Dark/Insane difficulty.). You can meditate anywhere(no fireplaces/characters needed) that wouldn't be considered dangerous(out of battle, not in the presence of enemies). Inside or outside.So far, the choice system is still here. I've been in situations in the game where I could, as an example, stop a crime or let it follow through. There are also sub-choices, which can sometimes be made after main choices have been made. Good/bad/etc ones are available.EDIT:Overall:Have since spent more hours playing the game and am enjoying it. The story is very much still that of The Witcher's, and the gameplay is very fun. Good combat, and there more options for interacting with characters you encounter than there were in last Witcher game.The game feels like it was made on PC, which is awesome. Same as the last game. Same level of detail in the enviornments, great graphics, and doesn't feel like some technically-constrained console port."coughs" Skyrim "coughs" Fallout

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												The Witcher is a dark, gritty, and mature RPG. It is probably one of the most grounded, and interesting RPG I've ever played. The Witcher itself is based on its famous novels written by Andrzej Sapkowski. Geralt of Rivia, The White Wolf, is a monster hunter for pay. Throughout Geralt's journey through Temeria for work, he is conflicted with political issues that arise after the events at Vizimia; this takes place during the Witcher 1. Geralt is now faced with treason, and is set out on a journey to clear his name. The Witcher 2 has a though provoking story that requires your attention. Books you pick up, as well as notes should be read. The books you find will tell you the history of the Witcher universe, and give you tips when fighting difficult opponents. You will also be making choices that actually do make a difference within the universe. The combat in the Witcher 2 is probably its weakest aspect. It is, however, much better than the combat system introduced in the Witcher 1. In the Witcher 2, you are required to roll around during almost any combat situation. This effectively makes signs, or any other defensive abilties obselete. The Witcher 2 requries a necessary playthrough as its story, characters, and universe are provoking. Even if the Witcher's combat system is medicore at best, it won't stop you from enjoying the numerous other aspects that the Witcher does correctly. Summary: Positive:+Story+High graphical fidelity+Unforgettable charactersNegative: -Combat

content:
2, 2016
												I started this game right after finishing The Witcher and the biggest improvement between the two is definitely the gameplay, namely combat.  I have very little bad to say about it other than that some of the strategies you can abuse (namely always have Quen up when fighting) make some of the fights a little dumb, but really any monster can kill you if you aren't paying attention and I really like that.  It makes the world feel very real that all monsters pose at least some threat throughout the entire game.I suppose the only other gripe I have is how poorly optimized the game is.  I should be able to run this maxed out with no frame drops at all, but there are times when I get pretty poor FPS and it has nothing to do with my system and everything to do with the game itself.  That said, there are some pretty fantastic sights to be seen in all the different locations the game takes you.  For a game that's about 5 years old, it has aged surprisingly well graphically.All the small negatives aside, this series is seriously one of my favorite of all time now.  The story telling is top notch.  The way the world and Geralt evolve as the story progresses is superbly done.  All progression feels extremely organic, especially from one game to another (where you can import saves that will keep your decisions intact ala Mass Effect so you can have YOUR Geralt through the entire series if you so wish). In addition to feeling organic...it just makes sense.  The way the politics change with your decisions or the decisions of other characters in the game...nothing feels contrived or silly because t's all justified by the world that has been crafted here.I can't recommend this game enough.  At times it gets frustrating because there are definitely some fights that will take a few tries to beat, but it is also rewarding in the sense of accomplishment, but also in the sense of story telling.  Any fan of RPGs where your decisions actual matter worth a damn should already be playing this, and if you have the stomach for it make sure to pick up the first game as well.  Both games took me just around 30 hours to beat (all quests for the given paths I had chosen completed) with a fair amount of exploration (which you should always take advantage of because you never know what cool weapons you'll find)...the ability to transfer saves from one game to the next (and even into The Witcher 3), really sells me on the idea that it's the right way to go if you're going to really get into the series.

About the game:You are Geralt of Rivia, a trained professional who hunts down monsters, a witcher. In Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, Geralt, by the kings choice, becomes deeply involved in the politics of the North, and pays a price for it. Blamed for things he did not do, Geralt is forced to clear his name. He's sent on a riveting tale of lies, schemes, and betrayal. Only Geralt can make it all right, for if he doesn't, who will?Pros:+Compelling story that really captures your attention+Vast world to explore+Combat is SOOO MUCH BETTER THAN WITCHER 1!+Lots of quest+Interesting characters+Awesome visually and has great sound effects+BoobsCons:-Hardest difficulty can be a ♥♥♥♥♥ for some of the major fights-Money (Orens) are hard to obtain and everything is expensive-To craft some weapons and armors, you need materials you can only get from earlier in the game. You need to know  what you need before you can even craft the armorOverall:Just completed this game today. 50 hours of gameplay doing just about everything on only one of the paths. In Witcher 2, you have 2 paths. So if you played the game fully twice, you would have 100 hours. For the money spent, it is well worth. I give it a bloody 10/10.

												This is a good RPG with some really impressive graphical and visual effects. Especially the lighting effects looks astonishing. The story is mature and rather complex, but I couldn't really appreciate it as much as others have done. Maybe it was because I haven't played the first game and therefore missed out on some parts of the overall story and the lore. Either way I thought it was a little bit too confusing at times, especially when the facial expressions and character animations wasn't very good.I also thought that the menus could've been better - they often felt slow, unresponsive and very irritating.But the thing that kept me playing was the superb combat! The feeling when you fought against a large number of enemies at the same time and you had to think tactical to survive was really rewarding!Overall, I enjoyed the game but was a little disappointed with the story, mostly because I've heard a lot good things about it. I do recommend the game though, especially if you want to test what your computer is capable of.

er 28, 2015
												The game is awesome! It has got it all: graphics, thick branching story, serviceable combat mechanics, and occasional nudity. The story is so rich that it actually bogs down the experience in the prologue. Tons of characters with their own public or hidden agendas drop in and out. After a while they become familiar enough, making the tons of plot twists impacting. The combat also has a rough start, in learning curve and outright weakness of the protagonist. Once you learn the basics the combat can make you feel like a skilled video game swordsman. Although, the hardest battles are a matter of long-winded tedium of exploiting the same combat techniques used in any other battle.All these elements compile to make an RPG that may not have the drowning, yet shallow, expanse of Bethesda games, but does dive deep in the few acts it contains.

												Although I've owned this since it came out, unfortunately my old PC wasn't able to run it... so when the Enhanced Edition came out the same week I got a new PC, I took it as a sign to finally make this backlog sin right. And it was worth the wait. If you played and liked the first game, you will love this. And if not, you will probably like it anyways, assuming action/RPGs interest you. Witcher 2 improves on every aspect of the first game - graphics (which are gorgeous), combat, story, and UI (inventory management, while better, still isn't quite perfect though). I can't really think of much bad to say about this game. It's really well made, the story/characters are interesting, and it's well-written and voiced. Witcher 2 also features a major branching story path at the end of chapter 1 that totally changes the rest of the game, which in turn adds a ton of replay value if you really want to see everything. All in all, this is an awesome game - highly recommended. Can't wait for #3!

Do yourself a favour and play this before The Witcher 3...... Not because The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt wouldn't work as a standalone game. Actually it does, and it does it very well.I got this game on sale for 2,99€ a few days back. My only problem with this game is that I have already finished The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt before starting this game. Truth be told, these games look much alike. So for a 2011 game The Witcher 2 looks great and feels great. If I had never played The Witcher 3 I would probably consider this one of thegreatest games I have ever played. The story, dialogue, acting, combat - all of it is there and it's good.But here is the problem; none of it is quite as good as with The Witcher 3. If you have never played The Witcher 3 you wouldn't know all the tiny things you're missing when you're playing The Witcher 2. But if you already have, you got to admit that in comparison The Witcher 2 feels rather small, clunky, limiting and occasionally claustrophobically one dimensional. This is not exactly fault of the game itself, but because the sequel happens to be probably the best game ever made.So do yourself a favour and don't do like I did. Don't go straight to The Witcher 3, but play this one (and even the first one if you can stomach the outdated experience) first or it will be very hard to come back. Personally I've found the story itself intriguing and craving more for the world of The Witcher. Right now, being used to the best coming back to something almost as good isn't quite cutting it anymore.I will finish this game eventually, but I wish I had started from here, just because I would've enjoyed it more.Regardless, this game is easily worth the money.

content:
4, 2014
												I have seen a lot of praise for this game especially for the PC platform on forums everywhere on the internet. And I have also seen a lot of this: "CDProjeKt Red is the only AAA game industry that cares about the PC platform"Well after playing the game this is what I have to say: The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a console game.Likes:- Great Cinematics and visuals. Clever use of post-process effects. Makes the graphics look great. Character models are very detailed.- Deep StoryDislikes:- Console style gameplay, all of it, the whole game- Keyboard and mouse controls are irritating. Tried the gamepad, the K+M issues were gone, but the gamepad has its own set of issues, the same issues for which i hate the gamepad in general. Finished the game with the keyboard and mouse except used the gamepad for arm wrestling(lol double meaning there).- You have to use a thing called as medallion to highlight pickup objects. Because it is very hard to see pickup objects manually. And that medallion thingy has got a cooldown. It's also hard to focus on pickup objects because of the player's 'running' to 'idle' state animation.- The minimap and the map wasn't exactly helpful. There will be some objective up a hill but you will end up in a cave directly below it. And the lack of fast travel just made it more irritating. It looks like the game wants me to memorize the directions to each place.- There will be some objectives that are right in front of you but you will have to circle around the entire town to reach that place since the player cannot jump over a fence or jump down to the floor below. This wouldn't have been a problem if it was only needed to be done once but you need to reach that same place again and again multiple times. The lack of fast travel again adds to the frustration.- The 'charm' option in dialogues always succeeds. No point in choosing other options.- Music is average at best. Not great use of sound either.- I hate memorizing stuff that isn't important to me. And the magic powers that the player has are in sign language, just made it more difficult to memorize. If it was English it would have been a bit easier. There were also some sign language puzzles. Who in the world knows sign language? There was a learning curve for me in this game. I don't usually expect a learning curve in a single-player game(after playing lots of games).- Some side missions get FAILED if you leave the area or progress the main story. I thought it was an open world RPG. Can't even finish objectives at my leisure. The game is linear for the most part.- The game wasn't technically impressive for me. There were a lot of loading zones/streaming levels(DOORS). Everything in the distance is either mist/fogged/depth of field blurred out. Basically everything you see in the far distance is of very low quality. And AFAIK there is no zoom functionality. And the third person camera helps hiding a lot of things. And I prefer realistic looking graphics than fantasy graphics even in a fantasy world.- Too many cutscenes. I wanted a game not a movie.- Show off.- Story can be overwhelming. Too many characters to keep track of, and characters are referred to in dialogues very directly some of which you haven't even seen or heard about yet. Poor presentation of story to the player. Ideally this should not be a reason for playing the game again.- Porny stuff doesn't add value to the game. This must have been a 'like' point for most people. People need to understand that this does not add value to the game. It might be needed for storytelling, but Witcher 2's scenes were deliberately inserted to increase player appreciation. If you are interested in such things go watch porn that is available for free on the internet. But don't praise a game because it has porny stuff in it.- On the other hand, the gameplay is completely childish and a kid cannot play this game because it has mature content.- The skill tree isn't very interesting. And you have to meditate to drink potions. Oh! Come onDoubtful:- I must be the only person who found the concept of a 'silver' sword ridiculous.Some useful Statistics:It's been more than 2 years since the release of Witcher 2. So some valid statistics are available. According to Steam achievements atleast 57.1% of players have started playing the game. And 13.8% of players have finished the game. That means only 24.17% players who have started playing the game have actually completed it. Ideally for a good single player game this percentage should be above 33. This probably means that most of the players either quit playing the game or got stuck somewhere indefinitely or they had better games to play or bought it just to watch the porny stuff in it and not to play the game. I hope this gives you enough reason for why this game is not recommended.Verdict : 78/100The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a console game.

content:
ry 12
												I love The Witcher and thoroughly enjoyed the original game for its depth, quality narative and pretty much everything else(Besides the combat which was still better than its successors). The Witcher 2 sad to say feels like a mere shadow of what it should have been. Where the first game felt immersive and fun to explore Assassins of Kings felt rigid and tedious. I actually had to force myself to finish it just because it felt so... Well... Not fun. I hate to say that but it's honestly how the game made me feel. Even during parts of the game where big stuff was happening it just felt straight up boring, and it just got worse as the game went on. Another thing I found strange is that pretty much nothing happens in this game. Sure you travel to different places in the world but for the most part nothing big happens at all, and even when stuff does happen it leaves a feeling of wanting more. Wanting more from a game isn't what one should feel while playing and engaging with a "Story rich RPG" you should feel like the story is big and mysterious leaving you guessing and wondering what could be next for the character. One last thing that I want to add is that The Witcher 2 is ludacrously short and ended abruptly seemingly out of no-where. I thought I was half way through when the credits started to roll leaving even more to be desired.All in all I realize that I'm being pretty critical but I mean if they were going to screw up the combat they could have at least given us a half way decent story. Oh well, hopefully The Witcher 3 will be better.

content:
12, 2015
												Can't really recommed this one. The graphics are ok, but nothing to write home about considering it is supposedly an 'enhanced edition'. Story and lore seem to be dense from what I can tell after roughly two hours.Unfortunately, combat and interaction are breaking this game for me. Combat is extremely clumsy, it basically boils down to button-mashing, where at no point you have real control over your character, but rather mash buttons as fast as humanly possible and see what the game decides to do.Combat animations are basic, very basic, you'll sometimes stun an enemy wielding a shield, and when you strike him see a cut-scene like animation where your character delivers a killing blow to an enemy that does not have a shield.I started the game on 'hard' difficulty, and it took me about 10 minutes to discover how to exploit weaknesses in the AI to a point where I basically go through the fights either with no health loss, the other possible outcome being dying a rather cheesy death due to the no-control combat system.If I had to describe the combat system with one word, I'm sorry to say that word would be 'garbage', it pretty much ruins an otherwise decent game.Interaction is similary painful, there is one interaction key (left mouse), which is also one of your main fighting keys, leading to all sorts of unintentional interactions during combat, especially since the 'hot zones' for interactions are placed badly. This also inhibits game flow, you'll sometimes run towards a ledge, and then have to move around trying to find the interaction zone to actually climb it, there is no fluid 'run up to the ledge and climb it' like you'd expect.Got this very cheap on sale, if I had bought it for full price I'd say it was wasted money.

content:
er 6, 2016
												A good game with bad momentsFor a game of its budget, there are some good cinematics, the characters are interesting, and its enough to keep you engaged, particularly now that the title is much cheaper.Now for the bad news. There are a few issues with the capacity to enrage you either into perservering or throwing your keyboard or controller across the room. I list them in no particular order below. It will sound like a negative review below. Actually it's not true, I just want people to be forewarned.Irritating mini-gamesThere a series of sort of mini-games where you need to mash buttons in a particular way or get punished for it repeatedly until through a sort of classical conditioning (like Pavlovs dogs) you get your food pellet of progress at the end. Examples of this are the bare knuckle boxing where a button will flash on the screen suddenly. The arm wrestle is another one of these where you have to struggle to keep your icon inside a bar using the mouse (in my case).A predilection for ♥♥♥♥ and bums.Okay I'm a guy and don't mind my hit of fantasy soft porn, but even I had to roll my eyes after practically every chick has gravity defying boobs and is either an angel or a ♥♥♥♥♥ (often literally).Alchemy - a pointless skill tree.I focused on swordfighting, why would you create slightly better potions that time out when you can consistently do more damage? Many games have these game balance issues but I found Witcher 2 didn't handle it as well. Crafting doesn't keep up with stuff that you simply find or get rewarded, a problem I've found in other titles also.An annoying badly lit maze.At one point of the game is a dwarven mine that is a type of basic maze. However its badly lit and you need to use Cat which gives you cat vision. The cat wears out. I thought about it and the main issue with getting lost was simple HUI (Human user interaction issues) like having sunlight sneak through under the bottom of the exit door, so the player takes a hint that that is the exit.More Classical Conditioning type puzzles.There are two in chapter 2 - completing a witch ritual to break a curse, you need to keep clicking things in a certain order, or you get forced to restart. It gets old quickly.The 2nd is seeing through the eyes of a dead assassin, you have to walk behind the other assassin step by step, I would do this and the sequence would restart and I would have to redo it. Now I wasn't doing anything blatantly dim, I would literally be behind the other guy and the sequence would restart. This is very frustrating and I'm now stuck.Overall, my 5 cents is that it has an inside group feel to the design, where the development team didn't bother to test some of their ideas, and realise 'hey' this part of the game is actually kind of crap. It's polished, but with dollops of developer bird poo on the dash 3.5/5.

content:
er 4, 2015
												I might've just fallen in love with the Witcher 2, and soon the whole series. This game is fantastic! The graphics are superb, it is a great PC port and it is incredibly enjoyable. It is a very well-made RPG that improves on pretty much everything the original did wrong/well. The combat here is satisfying as hell, the music is SUPERB, the characters are pretty damn good and there's just so much to love. However, it has very few problems. The targeting isn't particularly amazing, and the menus aren't too good either. However, you can get past these problems easily, and the game just becomes a whole other beast. Also, you would forget what buttons things are assigned to, but thankfully you can check and even change particular keys. You could find problems, such as not really knowing what every magic power does, but after experimenting you will know, Anyway, other than that, this is one of my favourite games and I love it so much. There's a lot to love and it is just a great game.Note: This game isn't openworld like Witcher 3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 8, 2015
												My experience with this game was just fantastic.It has a dark fantasy world with a realistic portrayal of characters and society. It borrows heavily from common themes found in universes like Lord of the Rings (e.g. races and creatures) but puts its own and dark spin on it. Being an adult rated does the whole game good as the story doesn’t hold back.The game sacrifices some character customization and range of combat abilities compared to other games - like Skyrim, for example, where there are now shields and bows in Witcher 2 - in favour of a deeper character of the protagonist which does the story a lot of good in my opinion.Technically it is very good to see a game go back to some “old school” principles of RPGs. There are no floating quest markers, no damage numbers, hardly any telegraphing no quest compass or combat log.Questing, combat and lore just feels very organic and the flow of the story comes natural and the narration of the story is unique as it is done by a sidekick of the protagonist.The game still looks very good, the only weak points being some aspects of character and facial animation. I do recommend the official combat rebalance mod from CD Project RED tough to improve combat and the “Enhanced camera” mod from nexusmods.com. After 65h of gameplay and having finished the game I still have withdrawal symptoms and wish there would be more to do, more quests, more fights and more exploring. The game does have replayability value because the whole middle part of the story completely branches out and changes how you get to the ending. Additionally, the combat style of Geralt can be customized quite a bit despite the aforementioned limitations. With that in mind however I now look forward to the open-world Witcher 3 a lot!

content:
er 23, 2016
												This game has been around for a long time now and I'm sure almost everyone has played it for at least a couple of hours.But maybe you jumped straight to Witcher 3 and want to come back to this one.I'll start with the PROS:- It has a beautiful story;- The characters are well-drawn and believable, almost all of them;- The choices you make matter;- Visually, it is a beautiful game, but not perfect;- The atmosphere is pleasant;- Ii is difficult, but in a good way.Here are some of the flaws:It could have been longer.The combat mechanics could have much been more complex,The saved games system is very poor. You can't overwrite or arrange saved games.The looting system is a joke for a RPG. You can steal almost everything in the game without consequences.The side quests could offer more details,You have to use potions before a fight and not during it.Vigor doesn't replenish while Quen is active, thus limiting your playstyle.Game crashed quite often.To sum up, Witcher 2 is a good game, but not perfect. You might like it or you'll be disappointed.For me, the story and characters helped me overlook some of flaws.It does take a while to be captivated by the game, so I advise you to be patient.

content:
er 6, 2016
												A good game with bad momentsFor a game of its budget, there are some good cinematics, the characters are interesting, and its enough to keep you engaged, particularly now that the title is much cheaper.Now for the bad news. There are a few issues with the capacity to enrage you either into perservering or throwing your keyboard or controller across the room. I list them in no particular order below. It will sound like a negative review below. Actually it's not true, I just want people to be forewarned.Irritating mini-gamesThere a series of sort of mini-games where you need to mash buttons in a particular way or get punished for it repeatedly until through a sort of classical conditioning (like Pavlovs dogs) you get your food pellet of progress at the end. Examples of this are the bare knuckle boxing where a button will flash on the screen suddenly. The arm wrestle is another one of these where you have to struggle to keep your icon inside a bar using the mouse (in my case).A predilection for ♥♥♥♥ and bums.Okay I'm a guy and don't mind my hit of fantasy soft porn, but even I had to roll my eyes after practically every chick has gravity defying boobs and is either an angel or a ♥♥♥♥♥ (often literally).Alchemy - a pointless skill tree.I focused on swordfighting, why would you create slightly better potions that time out when you can consistently do more damage? Many games have these game balance issues but I found Witcher 2 didn't handle it as well. Crafting doesn't keep up with stuff that you simply find or get rewarded, a problem I've found in other titles also.An annoying badly lit maze.At one point of the game is a dwarven mine that is a type of basic maze. However its badly lit and you need to use Cat which gives you cat vision. The cat wears out. I thought about it and the main issue with getting lost was simple HUI (Human user interaction issues) like having sunlight sneak through under the bottom of the exit door, so the player takes a hint that that is the exit.More Classical Conditioning type puzzles.There are two in chapter 2 - completing a witch ritual to break a curse, you need to keep clicking things in a certain order, or you get forced to restart. It gets old quickly.The 2nd is seeing through the eyes of a dead assassin, you have to walk behind the other assassin step by step, I would do this and the sequence would restart and I would have to redo it. Now I wasn't doing anything blatantly dim, I would literally be behind the other guy and the sequence would restart. This is very frustrating and I'm now stuck.Overall, my 5 cents is that it has an inside group feel to the design, where the development team didn't bother to test some of their ideas, and realise 'hey' this part of the game is actually kind of crap. It's polished, but with dollops of developer bird poo on the dash 3.5/5.

												Pros:- Stunning Graphic- Addicting Story- Awesome Gameplay- Alot of Side Quests (If you enjoy the game very much, try finishing all the side quests.)- Much more easier to cast a Witcher sign- Everything is better than Witcher 1Cons:- The game is hard to play (you die alot)- Need to almost mastered all skills in order to be able to slay your enemy- The game lags at some point- Alot of Side Quests (If you're just playing for the plot, ignore all the side quests.)Conclusion:Do you need to finish this to play Witcher 3: Wild Hunt? the answer is No, but i would recommend you to do so. The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings plays a very important role towards Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. The main reason on what will be happening in Witcher 3: Wild Hunt will be explain in this episode. Its okay if you didnt play the previous game, cause in this game it will have a flash back on what happened in Witcher 1.I will definitely recommend you to play this, cause for me it's very addicting, the story's good, the gameplay is awesome, a lot of extra and useful features compare to the Witcher 1. If you felt witcher 1 sucks, dont worry, this is nothing like witcher 1, try this out, and you'll get addicted to very soon.Its okay if you wanna just go ahead and start Witcher 3, you'll still enjoy it very much. But if you really desire to be a part of the whole trilogy, might as well give it a shot. Witcher 2 is definitely not dissapointing. Summary of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings : The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is about Geralt of Rivia been framed with the death of King Foltest, with the help of his friends, Geralt will find out who's responsible for the murder and clear his name.

content:
y 14
												Im going to start by saying that i played the witcher 3 before any of the others. I had never heard of the witcher until the third one came out and i decided i would try it after reading the reviews on it...many hours later the witcher 3 became my favorite game. During a steam sale i noticed that the witcher franchise was part of it so i bought the first and second game to get the full experience and use the game save transfer feature. I've already made a review on the first game which you can find here: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198064742467/recommended/20900So finally here is my review of the game:PROS:- very nice setting- very nice soundtrack- voice acting is good- lots of stuff to craft- heavy meaningful choices- characters that you care about- for small sections you viewed the game from other peoples perspectives- save transfer from the first game that changes the story in some minor waysCONS:- the menus are quite awkward to navigate and feel clunky- have to be in meditation to drink potions- doors kind of break fluidity (you'll understand if you play it)- in the lower difficulties it seems any fight can be won by spamming fast attack not letting the enemy attack- some skills seem very overpowered while some seem very underpoweredOverall i think that the Witcher 2 is a very fun game with a captivating story. Although it has its flaws it's definitely worth playing if you want to get the full witcher experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												This game is one of my favorite RPGs of all time. It has a really strong and compelling narrative and offers you plenty of chances to make choices that feel like they have some weight to them, though, perhaps not as much as the first game. The characters are mostly interesting, and the character development is definitely there. One of my favorite things about the story and characters is the moral ambiguity of it all. There is no clear distinction of good and evil between any of the sides. Simply two perspectives of what's right. The combat feels pretty fluid and I greatly enjoyed it. I liked how alchemy worked in the game, too. It's unnecessary in the first two difficulties, but in the higher ones, you'll find yourself greatly crippled if not using it. You cannot use potions in combat, so that adds some strategy to it. The game is absolutely beautiful on ultra settings, and it still looks pretty great even on lowers ones. The environment does at least. Nothing seems out of place in the world, the enemies are well designed and plenty creepy at times. They did a great job crafting the world.That doesn't mean it's without its issues, though. The combat does seem pretty fluid, but in higher difficulties you'll find yourself rolling endlessly across the ground with your foes in hot pursuit. Blocking is often times useless, and there is very noticeable input lag on occasion. There's also a noticeable disparity between easy and normal difficulties. Easy being ridiculously so, and normal for new players likely quite challenging in the beginning. Also, though I enjoyed how alchemy works, it also leads to an obvious issue that can break the fluidity/immersion of the game. Since you can't use potions outside of battle, this leads most people to entering a fight to see which potion they should use for which resistances or buffs, loading a quicksave, and then using the potion. I love the idea and how it fits into the Witcher lore, but it needs some work. Also, either a pro or a con depending on your preferences, but it's not really an open world, and there's very few side-quests. You go from hub to hub, each having a few explorable zones mainly comprised of small passages. As far as the side-quests go, there's around 8 or so for the first 2 acts, I believe. Not really all that many. It leads to it being a fairly short game as far as RPGs go. Mentioning the choices again, I loved how they were worked into the game and they did "feel" weighty, though they didn't really mean much. You still end up in more or less the same situations with the same people doing the same things. And then there's the much touted "Maturity" of the game. Yes, it may be much more so than many other RPGs, and it's definitely a dark game. The moral ambiguity definitely plays into this as well. With that said a lot of said "maturity" seems to stem from the idea that sex jokes are funny and adult. The characters way to often bring up "ploughing", at times it seems like every other sentence, though it's not really. It comes across as juvenile and cheap. There's mature themes throughout the game, though a lot of the perception of that seems attributed to the sexed up atmosphere. At least they removed the sex cards from the first game. I probably missed quite a few things, this is just some stuff that came to mind. Might edit it on occasion.I still recommend this game overall. It is quite enjoyable and the Witcher 3 is looking like a great game, so jumping into the series before that would probably be a good idea. It's on sale quite often, and even if not, it is easily worth $20 when it's not.

19, 2014
												This is one of the best games I've ever played.  First of all, it's freaking gorgeous.  The visual aspect alone makes it amazing, and I often find myself just looking around at all the little details.  As if the eye candy wasn't enough, the story is incredible.  It's quite involved, and all of your decisions carry weight, weather it be possitive or negative.  And the soundtrack. Holy ♥♥♥♥, the soundtrack. What a masterpiece. Filled with emotion and beauty, forboding and danger. Compliments the game perfectly and makes for an experience that most games can only hope to accomplish. Very few games have been able to grab a hold of my moral compass and really force me to think about potential outcomes like this one.  And the well executed combination of beautiful visuals, sound and story keep me coming back time and time again.  Highly recommended.

content:
, 2014
												Awesome continuation of The Witcher series that is a large improvement from its predecessor by a long-shot with better graphics, combat system, animation, and acting. It only makes me more excited for The Witcher 3 to be released. My criticisms for the game include the inability to increase inventory size, zero warning as to when side-quests will expire, limited animation during dialogue, and controls that are not very keyboard friendly. THIS GAME WILL NOT HOLD YOUR HAND FOR YOU. You are responsible for upgrading your armor/weapons, building your traits, and timing your potion intake in order to avoid having a overly hard-time with the game.  Didn't spend enough points on your signs? Good luck. Have only 30 seconds of potion when the boss battle starts? Oops. Didn't craft the sword that's twice as powerful as your current one? Tough. Also, THANK GOD the Romance cards are no longer a thing. That was a major problem I had with the first Witcher game, in that the cards had no value and served only as fan-service for horny male gamers. It kind of made me feel dirty as a male. In The Witcher 2, there is one sex scene with Triss. I hear you can sleep with the ♥♥♥♥♥s too, but I didn't mess around with that (too busy killing Drowners).

content:
, 2014
												BIG RECOMMENDATION!If you like real time action RPG fantasy games that is. One of the few non open-world games I've truly enjoyed from start to finish.Piecewise linear world, fairly big levels though, and a linear storyline you have to follow, but you can follow at your own pace, and it has enough side quests to keep from being monotonous. It is not open world, but it almost feels openworld. At the current pricepoint it is a steal, and easily shames most $59.99 new releases focused on the console market. This was a PC game first, and a console game second, meaning us PC gamers got an intelligent game with excellent keyboard mouse controls.There are two divergent and exclusive middle-game quest lines, so you have to replay pretty much the whole game at least once to see it all and do it all. I am going to take the time to go back and complete the second line.The quickplay arena mode is fun for practice and when you want some quick hack and slash, which you can abandon and walk away from when dinner is ready to come out of the oven.Personal quirk: one thing kept breaking the immersion for me: the voice actor for your character (Geralt) is the same voice actor who played Cal in Independence War 2, a game I have replayed at least six times; so everytime he speaks I think I am in space blasting spaceships, not in a forest hunting evil creatures and gathering herbs...I dearly hope they develop a sequel someday... HOLY CRAP, just went to duckduckgo.com and there is a Witcher 3 coming Spring 2015, and open world too  YEA!!!!

content:
, 2014
												I loved playing this game. The medieval setting is great, the imagery is colourful and immersive, and the plot is extremely well done, complex and multi-lateral. The game has no shame in throwing you right into the thick of the lore and plot line, demanding that the player be not only interested in progressing through the missions but also be actively involved in the political situations and racial tensions, forcing you to make decisions that dramatically change the plot and entire world constitution. If you don't like plot-driven stories, especially ones that demand a lot of understanding from the player, then this probbly isn't for you and you'll get a lot less out of it. The controls are a step up from the previous game, making them a lot more like typical ‘point-and-attack’ (or in this case swing and slash) video games, although strangely enough the interface took me a lot longer to get to grips with that the first game. The graphics are great too, though even the lowest settings make my computer want to melt into a puddle of molten goo. The voice acting is also decent in general, though if I hear some Scottish speaking dwarf yell at me “go plough your woeemaaannn!!” one more time….. All I would have to say in general is that the game would really benefit from a jump button. Having to click everytime you want to go up or down something can get quite tedious at times.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 1, 2015
												The epic scale of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is remarkable, but it's the power of choice in an unrelentingly ugly world that makes it unforgettable. Moral ambiguity has never been so powerfully presented: the decisions you make actually matter, and the outcomes are often unforeseeable and rarely as good as you'd hope.Geralt's quest is entirely personal, driven forward by a colorful, occasionally bizarre and surprisingly believable cast of characters that really brings the game alive. It's a fantastic and well-told tale, layered over very solid mechanical underpinnings: A flexible character development system, glorious eye candy, intense combat and more than enough secondary content to camouflage its very linear nature. It's dark, it's dirty, it's sometimes flat-out depressing and it's brilliant. Big improvement to the first game
