number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2014
												Since it's free and on sale this weekend, I'll go ahead and put my two cents in, which is to say that I highly recommend this title to anyone at all interested in RPGs.  Ok, I'll admit it - fatansy games aren't my favorite genre, and I tend to skip over most titles where magic is the primary component. To be honest it was the "adult content" that first caught my interest in the game - not that the sex and nudity isn't far tamer than what you can see on any given web site, I just wanted to see how far a video game would push the envelope on this kind of stuff.  Well, it didn't take long to figure out that while this game does have more adult stuff in it than any other game I've played, that content is by far the least compelling part of it.  The game looks amazing, with some of the best graphics out there - a little too good, if you turn on ubersampling, which very few systems can handle well.  The story is rich, complex and engaging, and well-told throughout, with incredible music and excellent voice-acting.  You would do well to play through the first Witcher game if you want the full backstory, but it's not strictly necessary.  Finally the magic system is well thought-out and easy to learn, which is great for someone like me who doesn't play a lot of fantasy games.  All in all, if you're a hardcore RPG or fantasy fan, this is definitely a game for you.  If you're on the fence about either, this game is a great introduction to the genre.  For this price you simply can't go wrong.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 8, 2015
												First time I've met witcher Geralt of Rivia was back in 1993 when first three Andrzej Sapkowski's books of witcher stories were published. Then novels followed and entire witcher saga has quickly become one of my most favorite fantasy worlds. I really love the dark atmosphere of entire world where every decision and deed have always two sides, many times both bad.After many years a PC game from witcher world has been announced. Oh boy I was sceptical about that, especially because it was being developed by small studio from Poland. Even though Poland is country of origin of the witcher books, it has also produced the Witcher TV series which was simply atrocious. Due to that I could not imagine that the depth of the novels could ever be successfully transferred to a computer game when even TV series failed so badly. However since I love RPG games and based on pretty positive reviews, I decided to give it a shot when final The Witcher Enhanced Edition was released, but I was rather expecting the worst. I couldn't have been more wrong. Don't remember if it was a week or two, but I've just played and played the game, days and nights until the grand finale.When The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings has been announced and first teasers started to emerge, I had no doubts it's going to be another must play for me. And as I wanted to enjoy the game to the maximum, I've armored myself with patience and waited. Didn't play when game was released, didn't even play when Enhanced Edition was released. I've waited just until recently when I got new gaming rig, I've installed it, set details to maximum, imported my final save from Witcher 1 and finally got into the game. It was worth of all the waiting for sure.The prologue itself was just spectacular in story telling, character's depth and even acting of completely virtual characters could put many real actors to shame. Unfortunately controls and combat expose their console origin, however I got used to it fast enough before it frustrated me. And once you get familiar with it, you can just focus on amazing mature and adult story which very few games could compare with. I've played both Roche's and Iorveth's paths and both were just awesome. There are also many indirect or hidden references to events from previous game or the novels, which gives the game another dimension for aware people. After almost 100 hours in game, I would still play more (if only there would be more content).The game has some negative sides as well, both in game concept and technical, I definitely do not want to deny that. However some "negatives" for some people are actualy "positives" for others.  For example many people were complaining that potions cannot be used during combat, but this exactly follows the concept from original books - so it is positive for me. On technical side there is a problem with excessive glow of some scenes and grainy shadows. How significant are other downsides for you depends on what you're looking for. So let's summarize:Positives: Amazing mature story Stunning visuals (with some exceptions - see Negatives section) Character's depth and acting Two different story lines The more you know the Witcher world, the more you enjoy the gameNegatives: Console port - negative impact on controls,combat, inventory etc. Exaggerative bloom and glow Grainy shadows The less you know the Witcher world, the less you enjoy the gameFrom the position of big fan of the books, the first game and entire Witcher universe, I positively recommend the game. As I have mentioned above, your knowledge of the witcher world and your enjoyment from the game are directly proportional.

content:
8, 2014
												I would happily call this game a 9/10.The voice acting is greatly improved over some of the zany terribleness in the first one.The combat, while not absolutely perfect, is streamlined from the previous entry, and fits the game and its environment very well.  You are forced to utilize your potions and upgrades if you want to be successful, and some of the extraneous things are removed from the last one.As with the Witcher 1, the game's story is mature and steeped in the politics of the world's nations.  For some, that might be a little heavy, bit in the day and age of Game of Thrones, I think most people will be able to enjoy it for its intrigue and depth.  It speaks volumes that I didn't skip through any of the story, even though I knew on several occasions that an NPC was about to talk for at least 15 minutes.The graphics and sound in this game are both great, no real drawbacks to be found there.The only thing that I would have liked to see improved on is the fact that the levels, while large, are disconnected from each other, which makes the game feel a little more linear than I would like.  This is something they've addressed by creating a fully open world for Witcher 3.I would strongly recommend playing through this now, in preparation for Witcher 3 when it hits.

content:
26, 2015
Side Quest SpoilerI was walking through a camp, there was this group of soldiers. It seemed like they were grouping up to bully on one of their comrades. They were telling him that he was unworthy of being a soldier because he crapped himself (wut!?). They punched him in the guts and walked away. I walked upto him, asked him if he was okay. He told me to leave unless I wanted to mock him. Having him as a companion would only make me look bad, he said. I asked him what the soldiers were talking about. He told me that he saw a ghost by the shoreline and pooped in his pants. He has been to battles, he was never that scared. He said that humans and ghosts are not the same. The other soldiers found out, and he became the crapper of the camp.I get a quest, to investigate the shore and the cliff on it. I talked to a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to find out more about a hut on that cliff. She told me a sad story about how there was this guy who healed others. One time, while he was busy on the job, someone killed all his children. He could not cope and killed himself by jumping off the cliff. I went to the hut on the cliff, searched the area around it. I found four graves behind the house. After reading the four names on the graves, I went through a secret tunnel beside the house and found... well a new quest. Then I went over to the shore and meditated until dawn. I walked towards the beach and saw the ghost. I told her that she ruined the life of an innocent man. The ghost told me that Mavrick, the crapper, was not innocent. She claimed that he was the one who murdered her and her two sisters and her father committed suicide. I told her that I was going to check whether she is telling the truth. I went back to the camp.I found Mavrick and CHOSE to tell him what the ghost had told me. He lashed out and told me that all monsters are the same, and I was a monster no different than his haunting specter. He said that he would take care of it himself and left. I went back to the beach at night. I found half of the crapper's blood stained body on the beach. The ghost then appeared. She laughed at me for trusting a "ghost born of suffering". She said that she got stronger by consuming the crapper's crapping half. I was surprised. I asked her who she was, and who murdered the sisters. She told me that their father did, because some soldiers defiled them and he couldn't abide the shame. Apparently, she devoured the crapper because the crapper's father made a deal with the specter and gave up his children, and she cnosumed the father too and felt stronger than she had ever before. She consumed Mavrick because she believed that "families should stick together". She thought that I would notice that there are only two sisters, and not three. I should have noticed that from the two female names on the grave stones.I fought her and defeated her. But I didn't win. An innocent man died because I made a wrong choice. I felt guilty. This was just a small side quest. The other ones also have their own rich detailed twists. And throughout the game, you make your own choices, you decide how you want to play it out. I'll leave it up to you to decide where the main story would then stand. The game play, the graphics, the environment, the characters: CD Projekt really outdid themselves when making this game. The combat mechanics are a bit hard to get used to, but it's seamless nonetheless. This is easily the best game that I have ever played.

content:
ry 17, 2014
												First off, know that The Witcher 2 is not a game that will hold your hand. If you're thinking about purchasing this, know that to get the most out of this game you need to be prepared to fully immerse yourself in the experience and pay attention to what is going in. This an adult, mature and complex game supported by rich lore and stunning visuals. The writing and storytelling is exceptional throughout and the moral ambiguity and choices are second to none. The gameplay, in particular the combat, is an acquired taste but offers a refreshing level of depth and potential for improvisation when compared to games in a similar genre. Sound design and voice acting is also of high quality, with the environments coming to life through impressive visual and audio support and characters each sporting distinct personalities and prejudices.It is also worth mentioning that if you have played the first Witcher game, your choices and gear will be reflected via an imported save in The Witcher 2, however the choices have limited effect and it is not necessary to play the first game to enjoy the second (however you will be at a slight disadvantage in some situations).In my honest opinion the experience as a whole is unparalleled, and The Witcher 2 is easily the most enjoyable and immersive RPG I have played in recent memory. I would also advise reading the books, in particular The Last Wish, Blood of Elves and Time of Contempt as these offer an interesting insight into the protagonist's past. But back to the game, overall I would highly recommend The Witcher 2 to anyone with at least a passing interest in the RPG genre, it is the definition of a complete gaming package with spectacular production values and a lasting impression.

content:
er 1, 2013
												the witcher was a global phenom that apparently the US wasnt ready for during its original debut in 2007.  having read 5.5 of the original 7 novels i have a better understanding of the story to date, especially having played the first game.  but none of that matters as, introduced in the first game, our hero geralt, has no memory of his past, ie the novels.  either way, the witcher series is about the story of geralt of rivia, a witcher or professional monster hunter, who is dragged into a twisting and turning story of political bull.sh.it that he wants nothing to do with, but unfortunitly cant escape.Unlike the first game of the series, the graphics are far more refined, the story is much more cohesive, complex and inline with what original stories would lead to, and is exactly what CDProjekt were hoping to create with the first game.  not only does choice matter, it is essential to the very core of the game.  every decision has a consequence, whether you see it now or at the end of your journey.  this is the type of game that bioware has wet dreams about but instead sells you a half ♥♥♥ copy of.  litteraly the 2nd half of the game takes completely different paths depending on a not so simple choice in the 1st chapter.one of my personal favorite features is "survivor mode"...dont be fooled, combat can be extremely difficult in this game, but entering the arena is a nice change of pace that will give you some, albiet, over exaggerated practice, but it is a great time killer that will keep you going in the hopes taht you can get your name of the leader board.  highly addictive and extremely punishing to the say the least, especially at higher difficulty levels.sure theres flaws, very few games are without but this is a game, that even if you didnt play the first, will have you from beginning to end leaving you begging for more, and unlike most games that claim to be of the same ilk....*cough* mass effect, there actually is more to do that you can not do because of the decisions that you made the first time around.Buy this game now, especially being 5$ as it will give you some back info to Witcher 3.  p.s. if you can get your hands on teh novels, they are fantastic and really give a detailed backstory on most characters, especially geralt and his close companions.  trust me you wont regret this purchase <3

content:
er 1, 2012
												Granted I haven't played the original Witcher due to the combat system in it, Witcher 2 is a lot better than its predecessor. The continuation of "multiple" paths in the story line to effect the overall outcome continues and with the well expected conclusion of the trilogy coming out soon, it's even funner now to replay through it again and relive the adventure.The storyline is intriguing and while some actions are locked in place, the overall feeling that you can change the environment is there. Most of the characters have advanced back storys that help add to them to make them feel more than just a single random person throwing quests at you and you don't have to kill the trolls!The combat style supports a miriad of different techniques such as support caster builds, ranged assassin builds, stealth attacks, straight out melee sluggers, and of course the balanced approach for all skill sets. The only thing really missing is the fact you still cannot use a dedicated ranged weapon such as a crossbow or longbow. While I am a fan of swordsmanship, there have been times when having a crossbow would of been a godsend.The gameplay mechanics are smooth and 99% of the time, balanced and fair. It's rare that I find a glitched area or a zone that results in a reset as in some games such as Fallout where you can get stuck on a cliff or stuck in mid-air while jumping. Visual appearances are, even on lower settings very eye-catching and the developers did a very good job in making sure that the game looks as good as it plays.Overall score: 8/10+ Good storyline and solid character builds+ Balanced combat styles that are both unique and worth using+ You can actually for the most part, stealth through the game if you really want a challenge+ Both routes can be set to a good or bad ending instead of fixed- Combat can be unforgiving when barrel rollingDefinetly would recommend this game to anyone who has played and enjoyed Skyrim, Assassins Creed, previous Witcher title, Tomb Raider, Fallout. Worth the time it takes to play and definetly worth playing through four times (both good endings, and both bad endings)

Character models, weapons, terrain and environment, you name it, it looks great!Only problem is, it is heavy on your system. But, you can play on the lower settings. *Little* changes. Like the view distance. In short, it's a great game developed by CD Projekt RED worth the buy.Have fun!

content:

												A masterpiece of modern medieval fantasy themed rpgs. This game has it all: a game of thrones, a tale of two lovers, kings and their quarrels and most importantly an amazing underlying lore that pulls you in from the start and does not let go until the ride ends with a bang at the end. Every character can be as fleshed out as you want them to be, and some may become more friendly than others depending on your choices. Your decisions will come to haunt you or to help you as the game progresses, because what choices you make have an impact on the game world and npcs will treat you differently. You get the sense that the world changes around you and that there is an urgency to all your actions. In this game you are never safe, be it from hostile foes to swindlers and thieves to deceptive traps set in the world. And the  game does all of this with a masterful score of music and amazing visuals to boot. The only reason for the nine is the fact that it is not quite an open world adventure like that of GTA or Skyrim, but just wait until the Witcher 3!

												The Witcher 2 is one of the best RPGs ever made. It will bring hours of enjoyment if you enjoy deep story telling and a less romantic image of the Medieveal Fantasy. Where instead of saving the damsel in distress and riding home on a road of rose pedals, everyone hates you and wants you dead unless theres a f***ing monster to kill for them, then you're all right. I loved the game's story, as it offers more than just "You are thy chosen one and henceforth must slay'th the great evil {insert villianous name/monster) in accordance with the great prophecy." It allowed for story telling where there were consequences for your actions and not everything is a simple good or bad choice. Its a RPG that lets you breath the reality of the situation and immerse yourself in the role of the White Wolf, the Witcher, Geralt of Rivia. If you haven't purchased this game you are honestly missing out on one the greatest representations of gaming that the world has seen - Yes I know Witcher 3 is out and that it is equally amazing but I'm not writing a review for that game. In closure, if you have doubts, wait for a steam sale and pick it up on the cheap. Either way its worth having and I find myself recommending this game again and again for people who have never heard of Geralt of Rivia, the Witcher.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 17, 2014
												First off, know that The Witcher 2 is not a game that will hold your hand. If you're thinking about purchasing this, know that to get the most out of this game you need to be prepared to fully immerse yourself in the experience and pay attention to what is going in. This an adult, mature and complex game supported by rich lore and stunning visuals. The writing and storytelling is exceptional throughout and the moral ambiguity and choices are second to none. The gameplay, in particular the combat, is an acquired taste but offers a refreshing level of depth and potential for improvisation when compared to games in a similar genre. Sound design and voice acting is also of high quality, with the environments coming to life through impressive visual and audio support and characters each sporting distinct personalities and prejudices.It is also worth mentioning that if you have played the first Witcher game, your choices and gear will be reflected via an imported save in The Witcher 2, however the choices have limited effect and it is not necessary to play the first game to enjoy the second (however you will be at a slight disadvantage in some situations).In my honest opinion the experience as a whole is unparalleled, and The Witcher 2 is easily the most enjoyable and immersive RPG I have played in recent memory. I would also advise reading the books, in particular The Last Wish, Blood of Elves and Time of Contempt as these offer an interesting insight into the protagonist's past. But back to the game, overall I would highly recommend The Witcher 2 to anyone with at least a passing interest in the RPG genre, it is the definition of a complete gaming package with spectacular production values and a lasting impression.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2013
												the witcher was a global phenom that apparently the US wasnt ready for during its original debut in 2007.  having read 5.5 of the original 7 novels i have a better understanding of the story to date, especially having played the first game.  but none of that matters as, introduced in the first game, our hero geralt, has no memory of his past, ie the novels.  either way, the witcher series is about the story of geralt of rivia, a witcher or professional monster hunter, who is dragged into a twisting and turning story of political bull.sh.it that he wants nothing to do with, but unfortunitly cant escape.Unlike the first game of the series, the graphics are far more refined, the story is much more cohesive, complex and inline with what original stories would lead to, and is exactly what CDProjekt were hoping to create with the first game.  not only does choice matter, it is essential to the very core of the game.  every decision has a consequence, whether you see it now or at the end of your journey.  this is the type of game that bioware has wet dreams about but instead sells you a half ♥♥♥ copy of.  litteraly the 2nd half of the game takes completely different paths depending on a not so simple choice in the 1st chapter.one of my personal favorite features is "survivor mode"...dont be fooled, combat can be extremely difficult in this game, but entering the arena is a nice change of pace that will give you some, albiet, over exaggerated practice, but it is a great time killer that will keep you going in the hopes taht you can get your name of the leader board.  highly addictive and extremely punishing to the say the least, especially at higher difficulty levels.sure theres flaws, very few games are without but this is a game, that even if you didnt play the first, will have you from beginning to end leaving you begging for more, and unlike most games that claim to be of the same ilk....*cough* mass effect, there actually is more to do that you can not do because of the decisions that you made the first time around.Buy this game now, especially being 5$ as it will give you some back info to Witcher 3.  p.s. if you can get your hands on teh novels, they are fantastic and really give a detailed backstory on most characters, especially geralt and his close companions.  trust me you wont regret this purchase <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												I'm not typically compelled to review games I purchase on Steam, but the Witcher 2 so thoroughly surprised me I had to say something.I had long avoided the Witcher series out of dislike for the apparently cliche main character, but as there was an absence of good RPGs to play this summer I picked them up during the sale on a lark. The first game I played a couple chapters of, but ultimately couldn't get into it; I had played Neverwinter Nights to death earlier in my life, and the similarities of the Aurora engine were just so strong that I found myself burnt out.So I booted up the Witcher 2. I was instantaenously amazed by the graphics, despite the game's age. The visual fidelity worked to support what felt like a living, breathing world, and within the first hour I was already hooked on the story. The characters, while suffering from stiff facial animations, are backed up by well-written dialogue and quality voice-acting. There is a moment early in the game where Geralt re-unites with his companions in an inn and, while the "party meeting around a table" is a genre staple, the presentation was so well done I felt like I was in a Lord of the Rings scene.The game's mechanics aren't quite as engrossing as its narrative. The combat is servicable, and feels smooth and well-animated for the most part; targeting hitches, stiff dodging, and difficulty landing magic attacks do weigh down the experience. Likewise, the inventory management and map menus are frustratingly clumsy given their importance to the game. The combat, movement, and interface were all clearly designed for a gamepad, but I found the radial quick-menu lacking in precision; often, I had to resort to the d-pad to navigate, rather than just flicking a stick in the required direction. These quibbles can be just enough to pull you out of the game for a little longer than you'd like, but the environments and the story will always pull you back in. It's not open-world in the sense that Skyrim is; areas have defined (though branching) paths through them. Thankfully they are laid out naturally enough to stop you from feeling like you're on a theme-park ride dictated by arbitrary invisible fences and, while your mileage may vary, I found that the relatively rigid environment was offset by the narrative freedom. You may not be able to go everywhere you can see, but nowhere you go feels empty or lifeless.Lastly, just to address the issue that initially put me off this series; no, there is no character creation. Geralt is Geralt: You can't make him an elf or dwarf, or change his class or gender, or give him a haircut. You can allocate points to swordsmanship, magic, or alchemy, but you'll still always be a Witcher. But as the decisions you make start to shape the world around you, he will very much start to feel like your character, and in ways much more significant than a different name or appearance could provide.To sum it all up: This is a well-polished and engrossing game with a strong narrative, visuals that are both technically and artistically beautiful, and a world so well-realized that even accidentally unequipping your pants for the 20th time can't take away from it. If you think you might have even the slightest interest in trying this game, buy it. You will fall in love.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												So with the release of the Witcher 3 i decided it was time to play at least one of the Witcher games sitting unplayed in my library and i decided to jump into the Witcher 2. I ended up really enjoying this game and it's one of the better RPG's i've played i a while. The quests are brilliant some nice depth and detail to them instead of endless fetch quests like a lot of other RPG's.The games morality system is a lot superior is well with a lot of decisions not always being morally clear and with consequences or benefits not being evident till later. A decision you make early in the game greatly effects the story later giving you good reason to replay the game. It's not all good though. I didn't really enjoy the combat system which feels a bit clunky and takes getting used to though it does promote taking a more tactical approach to combat utilizing different spells and potions.The Good:- great story of political intrigue with a really likeable protaganist in Geralt who seems one-dimensional at first but is actually a complex character- brilliant quests that have more depth and substance compared to the usual RPG quests- excellent morality system where the right (or wrong) choice is not always clear and keeps you guessingThe Bad:-terrible tutorial that doesn't really help a whole lot -clunky awkward combat that can at times be too easy or too hard when you get swarmed by enemies. Though it does encourage you to approach combat more tactically using spells and potions but the fact you can only drink potions outside combat can leave you ♥♥♥♥ed with a surprise encounter-the save system is awful. You cant choose save slots to save in or to overwrite, instead each time you save the game creates a new save file leaving your save folder completely overloadedOverall this is a really enjoyable RPG despite the few flaws and is still worth playing even though it'll be now overshadowed by it's sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
12, 2014
												The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is an excellent RPG that shows just how far Polish developers can stretch 10 million dollars. The game is gorgeous, challenging, and engaging. There is a lot to like about the Witcher 2 but I’m most pleased with how it doesn’t treat you like an idiot. Puzzles and quests can require a lot of in game research to solve and the game never holds your hand. When everything comes together you really feel accomplished.There is a whole lot to love about this highly replayable game. Get it.While you don’t need to have played the original game to understand Witcher 2 you can import saved games from the original game (which affects your starting equipment as well as a few other things). You can download some saved games below.http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/180/?

												This game takes you on a journey of never ending fun and excitement. It's not just the usual "go to the dungeon and clear it out" sort of game it's more of an "Go to the dungeon, get materials to defeat and epic monster that you will battle soon... and oh! While you're at it defeat the boss" kind of game. I'm sure you will never get bored. The story and gameplay of this game is great, especially how they can make the antagonists really hateful and protagonists loveable, also decions somewhat matter you do not get any rewards though your choices will have its consequences. Once you think that you are over with the game you're probably wrong because you haven't explored "everything" yet. This is game is great that's all I can say 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2014
												A must play for any RPG fan.The Witcher game series is what you get when fans of a great novel series come together and create a game based on the novels.  The game worlds have so much lore and detail.More games should be created from top notch novels.CD Projekt Red always does a great job at adding all kinds of improvements to the game after release as well.Pros: Drastically enhanced combat system from the previous installment of The Witcher. Causality: Different choices you make at points in the game can have a major impact on your immediate and future experience playing through the story. Able to create your own Witcher fighting style by selecting different abilities from 4 categories (Swordman, Magic, Training, and Alchemy). Tons of things for the player to do/explore that stray from the main quest line. Improves on just about every aspect of the game series.Cons: Sometimes preparing the right potion / oil for a specific monster can be tricky as you can no longer meditate in combat.
